  • Post-Event Fallout: Portugal’s cancellation contributed directly to the FIA’s decision to ban Group B at the end of 1986.

The 1986 Rallye de Portugal serves as a sobering reminder of rallying’s most dangerous era—where speed, spectacle, and safety tragically collided.

events.title: 1986 Safari Rally (Kenya)
events.bio: Björn Waldegård delivered another masterclass in endurance, guiding the Toyota Celica TCT through Kenya’s brutal terrain to claim a record-breaking fourth Safari Rally win.
events.details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1986 Safari Rally (Kenya)

Date: March 27–31, 1986

Start Location: Nairobi, Kenya

Finish Location: Nairobi, Kenya

Total Distance: 4,100 km

Surface: Gravel

The 1986 Safari Rally remained the WRC’s ultimate test of durability, navigation, and experience. Björn Waldegård—known as the Safari master—secured his fourth win in Kenya, showing calm control and mechanical sympathy through deep water crossings, punishing gravel, and oppressive heat. The Toyota Celica TCT proved again that in Africa, it wasn’t the fastest that won, but the toughest and smartest.

🗺️ Route Details

Covering over 4,000 kilometers across Kenya, the route featured wildlife zones, deep mud, and remote checkpoints:

  • Rift Valley & Amboseli: Dry plains, volcanic dust, and long straights interrupted by waterlogged traps and washouts.
  • Mount Kenya Foothills: Rocky elevation changes and sudden weather shifts tested both power and grip.
  • Night Loops: Long dark stages with navigation based solely on tulip roadbooks—no pacenotes allowed.

Pace was determined as much by preservation as speed, and many Group B cars failed to finish due to mechanical breakdowns or off-road excursions.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Björn Waldegård & Fred Gallagher (Toyota Celica TCT)

2nd Place: Shekhar Mehta & Yvonne Mehta (Nissan 240RS)

3rd Place: Erwin Weber & Klaus Wicha (Volkswagen Golf GTI 16V)

Waldegård’s victory further cemented his legacy in African rallying—his smooth approach and strategic pace made the difference in a rally that chewed up and spat out faster but less reliable rivals.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Toyota Celica TCT: Turbocharged RWD rally car built for long-distance endurance—stable, tough, and designed for African terrain.
  • Nissan 240RS: RWD, rugged, and dependable, often outperforming more advanced cars in extreme rally marathons.
  • Volkswagen Golf GTI 16V: Lightweight and well-balanced FWD entry that delivered consistency and agility over long stretches.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Open Road Format: No closed special stages—drivers navigated public roads and rally routes while avoiding traffic and wildlife.
  • Mechanical Stress: Long liaisons and brutal terrain wore out suspensions, brakes, and cooling systems quickly.
  • Fatigue Management: Crews spent hours in the car daily, making focus and hydration as critical as tire pressure.

The 1986 Safari Rally proved again that mastery in Kenya came not from brute force but from consistency, resilience, and an unshakeable focus—traits Björn Waldegård embodied to perfection.

events.title: 1986 Tour de Corse – Rallye de France (Corsica)
events.bio: The 1986 Tour de Corse ended in heartbreak with the fatal crash of Henri Toivonen and Sergio Cresto while leading. No winner was declared, and the event marked a turning point that led to the end of Group B.
events.details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1986 Tour de Corse – Rallye de France (Corsica)

Date: May 2–4, 1986

Start Location: Ajaccio, Corsica

Finish Location: Rally not officially completed

Total Distance: 1,096 km of special stages

Surface: Asphalt

The 1986 Tour de Corse will forever be remembered for the devastating loss of Henri Toivonen and co-driver Sergio Cresto, who crashed fatally on Stage 18 while leading the rally. Their Lancia Delta S4 plunged off a cliff and exploded upon impact, leaving no chance of survival. The accident sent shockwaves through the motorsport world and immediately triggered the FIA’s decision to cancel Group B for the 1987 season. No official winner was declared.

🗺️ Route Details

Known as the “Rally of 10,000 Corners,” Corsica’s narrow tarmac stages offered zero margin for error:

  • Zérubia–Palneca: The fatal crash occurred here—a high-speed stage bordered by steep ravines and stone walls.
  • Pont de Vivario and Bocognano Loops: Technical stretches with no runoff, demanding perfect car placement and pacing.
  • Sartène–Piana: Fast and flowing but lined with danger at every bend.

While the roads were dry and conditions optimal, the combined power and fragility of Group B machines turned every misstep into a potential disaster.

🏆 Results

No winner was declared following the fatal crash of Car #4.

Toivonen and Cresto were leading by a significant margin before the incident. Out of respect and shock, the event’s competitive significance was overshadowed entirely by tragedy.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Lancia Delta S4: Twincharged, AWD Group B car delivering unmatched performance—but also unforgiving in failure.
  • Peugeot 205 T16 E2, Audi Sport Quattro E2: Also competing, though team morale and focus collapsed after the tragedy.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Zero Margin Asphalt: Corsica’s roads left no room for driver error—every misjudged line risked catastrophe.
  • Vehicle Complexity: Group B machines pushed limits of power and control, outpacing available safety standards.
  • Mental Pressure: The psychological toll of leading at such speeds through danger zones made every moment high-risk.

The 1986 Tour de Corse was the tipping point for Group B. Henri Toivonen’s death was more than a tragedy—it was a wake-up call that the spectacle had gone too far. His legacy remains as one of rally’s brightest talents, lost at the height of his powers.

events.title: 1986 Acropolis Rally (Greece)
events.bio: Juha Kankkunen survived Greece’s brutal gravel stages to earn another victory in the Peugeot 205 T16, reinforcing his title bid with consistency and endurance.
events.details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1986 Acropolis Rally (Greece)

Date: June 1986

Start Location: Athens, Greece

Finish Location: Athens, Greece

Total Distance: ~850 km of special stages

Surface: Gravel

The 1986 Acropolis Rally once again delivered carnage and attrition, as Greece’s rock-strewn mountain roads and scorching heat tested every component—and every crew. Juha Kankkunen kept calm amid chaos, piloting the Peugeot 205 T16 to another victory as his rivals faltered. His measured approach allowed him to avoid the mechanical and navigational pitfalls that consumed many competitors in one of the WRC’s most demanding events.

🗺️ Route Details

The stages wound through the punishing terrain of mainland Greece:

  • Mount Parnassus: Dry and dusty roads with sharp rock edges and treacherous drop-offs.
  • Delphi Region: Heat, loose gravel, and narrow cliffside paths demanded both speed and restraint.
  • Kalambaka Loops: Long liaisons and rough sectors that battered suspension and fuel systems.

Extreme temperatures added another layer of difficulty, as engines, brakes, and even drivers approached their breaking points on each leg.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Juha Kankkunen & Juha Piironen (Peugeot 205 T16)

2nd Place: Markku Alén & Ilkka Kivimäki (Lancia Delta S4)

3rd Place: Malcolm Wilson & Nigel Harris (Ford RS200)

Kankkunen’s win was not built on raw speed but on survival, consistency, and intelligence—key attributes that shaped his path to the 1986 World Championship.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Peugeot 205 T16: Durable and adaptable—its cooling system and rugged suspension gave it an edge in the heat and dust.
  • Lancia Delta S4: Incredibly fast and agile, but suffered intermittent mechanical issues on the roughest stages.
  • Ford RS200: Lightweight and promising, but limited experience in long-haul endurance rallies showed in stage consistency.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Rock Hazards: Tire damage and undercarriage strikes ended many contenders’ rallies prematurely.
  • Heat Management: Cockpit temperatures reached extreme levels—driver and machine fatigue were ever-present.
  • Route Complexity: Long stages without full recce and limited service forced cautious pace strategies.

The 1986 Acropolis Rally reinforced a timeless WRC lesson—survival beats speed when the terrain turns against you. And Kankkunen, calm as ever, let the others fall before raising the winner’s trophy.

events.title: 1986 Rally New Zealand
events.bio: Juha Kankkunen continued his dominant 1986 campaign with a composed and commanding drive through New Zealand’s flowing gravel roads in the Peugeot 205 T16.
events.details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1986 Rally New Zealand

Date: July 1986

Start Location: Auckland, New Zealand

Finish Location: Auckland, New Zealand

Total Distance: ~500 km of special stages

Surface: Gravel

The 1986 Rally New Zealand delivered smooth gravel, high speeds, and beautiful scenery—but it was Juha Kankkunen who stole the show. In perfect harmony with the Peugeot 205 T16, he flowed through the twisty, cambered roads with confidence and composure, leaving rivals in the dust. The rally reinforced his title credentials as he secured another Group B victory with clinical precision.

🗺️ Route Details

New Zealand’s rally stages are celebrated for their rhythm and smooth gravel surfaces:

  • Maramarua Forest: Fast and flowing with wide corners and forgiving shoulders.
  • Rotorua Region: Undulating gravel with cambered turns that reward fluidity and balance.
  • Whangarei Stages: Mixed elevation and consistent grip allowed high average speeds throughout the weekend.

The absence of extreme terrain or weather meant performance came down to setup, co-driver rhythm, and clean execution—Kankkunen and Piironen nailed them all.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Juha Kankkunen & Juha Piironen (Peugeot 205 T16)

2nd Place: Malcolm Wilson & Nigel Harris (Ford RS200)

3rd Place: Jorge Recalde & Martin Christie (Renault 11 Turbo)

With another solid win, Kankkunen extended his championship momentum, proving he could dominate both rugged marathons and high-speed precision rallies alike.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Peugeot 205 T16: Lightweight, agile, and extremely fast on flowing gravel—near unbeatable in the hands of Kankkunen.
  • Ford RS200: Gained traction as a viable contender on fast gravel, but reliability still a limiting factor.
  • Renault 11 Turbo: Underdog with excellent drivability and durability—strong finish in a field dominated by AWD monsters.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • High-Speed Rhythm: Mistimed pacenotes or overdriving broke the natural flow needed to win in NZ.
  • Clean Line Discipline: Maintaining consistent exits and weight transfer was key to maximizing corner speed.
  • Setup Consistency: Tire and suspension tuning for mid-speed grip and minimal oversteer gave top teams the edge.

The 1986 Rally New Zealand rewarded calm, calculated aggression—qualities Kankkunen had mastered as he surged toward a championship-winning season.

events.title: 1986 Rally Argentina
events.bio: Massimo 'Miki' Biasion claimed his first World Rally Championship victory on the rough roads of Argentina, mastering the Lancia Delta S4 over long, punishing gravel stages.
events.details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1986 Rally Argentina

Date: July 26–30, 1986

Start Location: Córdoba, Argentina

Finish Location: Córdoba, Argentina

Total Distance: ~1,000 km of special stages

Surface: Gravel

The 1986 Rally Argentina tested durability and pace across high-speed gravel, river crossings, and mountainous terrain. Miki Biasion delivered a breakthrough victory in the Lancia Delta S4, navigating the harsh roads and wide-ranging conditions with precision and maturity. His win marked a personal milestone and further proved the Delta S4’s prowess on South American soil.

🗺️ Route Details

The rally featured long and physically demanding stages across Argentina’s rugged interior:

  • Traslasierra Region: Technical gravel stages with tight corners, riverbeds, and variable elevation.
  • Pampas Plains: Wide-open high-speed stretches that punished any lapse in concentration.
  • Calamuchita Valley: Rocky mountain roads with loose stones and narrow passes along ridgelines.

Weather played a role in tire strategy, with dry heat and scattered storms transforming stage surfaces in a matter of hours.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Massimo Biasion & Tiziano Siviero (Lancia Delta S4)

2nd Place: Jorge Recalde & Martin Christie (Renault 18 GTX)

3rd Place: Carlos Reutemann & Luis Di Palma (Peugeot 504)

Biasion’s win not only marked his emergence as a world-class contender but also demonstrated Lancia’s ability to dominate in brutal, long-format events far from Europe.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Lancia Delta S4: Powerful twincharged AWD machine with a balance of raw speed and rugged endurance—perfect for Argentina’s extremes.
  • Renault 18 GTX: A proven local favorite with reliability and strong suspension, ideal for long gravel endurance rallies.
  • Peugeot 504: Older but durable RWD platform that remained competitive in national-level endurance stages.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Mechanical Survival: Suspension and cooling systems were pushed to their limits over long rocky stages.
  • Local Terrain Knowledge: Regional drivers used their familiarity with loose gravel transitions to challenge factory entries.
  • Concentration Under Fatigue: With long loops and few breaks, mental endurance was as critical as mechanical reliability.

The 1986 Rally Argentina gave the world a new winner and reminded everyone that in endurance rallies, smart driving often beats raw aggression. Miki Biasion’s calm determination paid off in full.

events.title: 1986 1000 Lakes Rally (Finland)
events.bio: Markku Alén thrilled the home crowd with a classic Finnish drive, taking victory through the fast, flowing gravel of the 1000 Lakes in his Peugeot 205 T16.
events.details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1986 1000 Lakes Rally (Finland)

Date: August 29–31, 1986

Start Location: Jyväskylä, Finland

Finish Location: Jyväskylä, Finland

Total Distance: 478 km of special stages

Surface: Gravel

Finland’s legendary 1000 Lakes Rally once again delivered high-speed thrills, massive jumps, and precise rhythm. Markku Alén, at home on these blisteringly fast stages, combined local knowledge with the Peugeot 205 T16’s agility to fend off a talented field and claim victory. His performance on familiar ground highlighted the razor-edge commitment required to win in the land of crests and corners.

🗺️ Route Details

The rally featured Finland’s signature mix of flow, precision, and bravery:

  • Ouninpohja: Iconic and deadly—flat-out jumps, blind crests, and unforgiving high-speed descents.
  • Laukaa: Fast and smooth with sweeping rhythm-based sections ideal for experienced Finnish drivers.
  • Ruuhimäki: Natural jumps and cambered bends challenged suspension setup and throttle control.

Weather was dry and consistent, making maximum attack viable for those willing to push the limits with courage and trust in their pacenotes.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Markku Alén & Ilkka Kivimäki (Peugeot 205 T16)

2nd Place: Juha Kankkunen & Juha Piironen (Peugeot 205 T16)

3rd Place: Hannu Mikkola & Arne Hertz (Audi Quattro E2)

Alén’s victory gave the home fans a reason to cheer, as he held off Kankkunen in a tight intra-team battle while demonstrating total mastery of Finland’s flowing stages.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Peugeot 205 T16: Perfectly suited for high-speed gravel—light, responsive, and planted in fast corners and long jumps.
  • Audi Quattro E2: More powerful but heavier—struggled in the tightest sections compared to Peugeot’s agility.
  • Lancia Delta S4: Competed strongly early on, but reliability and setup issues limited its final performance.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Absolute Commitment: Many corners and jumps were taken flat-out based solely on pacenote memory.
  • Jump Management: Drivers had to position cars perfectly on takeoff to avoid loss of control on landing.
  • Home Pressure: For Finnish drivers, the rally was both a showcase and a proving ground—with no margin for error.

The 1986 1000 Lakes Rally rewarded bravery, rhythm, and precision—and Markku Alén delivered all three in a flawless performance before an ecstatic home crowd.

events.title: 1986 Rallye Sanremo (Italy)
events.bio: Miki Biasion initially claimed victory at the 1986 Sanremo Rally, but controversy over Peugeot’s disqualification led to the results being annulled by the FIA—turning triumph into turmoil.
events.details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1986 Rallye Sanremo (Italy)

Date: October 6–10, 1986

Start Location: Sanremo, Italy

Finish Location: Sanremo, Italy

Total Distance: 512 km of special stages

Surface: Asphalt and gravel

The 1986 Sanremo Rally began as a showcase of Italian talent and mixed-surface mastery, but ended mired in one of the most controversial decisions in WRC history. Miki Biasion led home a Lancia 1-2 finish after the Peugeot team was disqualified mid-event over alleged illegal side skirts—a protest widely seen as politically motivated. Peugeot appealed, and the FIA later annulled the entire event, making it the only WRC round with no official results for the season.

🗺️ Route Details

Sanremo's dual-surface layout tested tire choice, adaptability, and co-driver rhythm throughout Ligurian backroads:

  • Andagna–Pigna: Tight and twisting tarmac stage through ancient hill towns with little margin for error.
  • Colle Langan: Gravel stage with rapid elevation change and treacherous hairpins.
  • Monte Ceppo: Long loop with mixed surfaces that pushed suspension tuning and driver focus to the limit.

Changing weather further complicated tire strategy, making team calls vital to overall performance—though none of it would ultimately count toward the title.

🏆 Results

No official WRC winner declared. Event annulled by FIA due to disqualification controversy.

Original 1st Place (annulled): Miki Biasion & Tiziano Siviero (Lancia Delta S4)

Original 2nd Place: Markku Alén & Ilkka Kivimäki (Lancia Delta S4)

Peugeot Status: Entire team disqualified mid-rally for “illegal side skirts”—later overturned by FIA appeal.

The annulment had major implications on the championship standings and ignited long-lasting debates over fairness, favoritism, and regulation consistency in Group B’s final season.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Lancia Delta S4: Dominated the leaderboard with agile tarmac handling and explosive gravel traction—its success overshadowed by the FIA decision.
  • Peugeot 205 T16: Arguably faster and more reliable—excluded on questionable grounds despite being legal under scrutineering guidelines.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Mixed Surfaces: Rapid surface changes within a single stage challenged tire compounds and suspension tuning.
  • Political Pressure: Home advantage, media attention, and regulation gray areas fueled high-stakes decisions.
  • Regulatory Fallout: The event’s cancellation left teams frustrated and disillusioned—many viewed it as the moment Group B lost its legitimacy.

The 1986 Rallye Sanremo was meant to be a celebration of Italian rallying excellence, but became a symbol of controversy that hastened the end of rallying’s most powerful era.

events.title: 1986 Rallye Côte d’Ivoire (Ivory Coast)
events.bio: Björn Waldegård once again proved his mastery of African endurance rallies, winning the Côte d’Ivoire event in punishing conditions and securing vital points in a drivers-only round.
events.details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1986 Rallye Côte d’Ivoire (Ivory Coast)

Date: November 1986

Start Location: Abidjan, Ivory Coast

Finish Location: Abidjan, Ivory Coast

Total Distance: ~4,700 km

Surface: Gravel

The 1986 Rallye Côte d’Ivoire was one of the final marathons of the Group B era, run under extreme conditions across West Africa. As a drivers’ championship-only round, no manufacturers’ points were awarded, but that didn’t dull the competitive edge. Björn Waldegård and Fred Gallagher delivered a textbook performance in the Toyota Celica, surviving the brutal distances, heat, and mechanical attrition to claim victory once again in Africa.

🗺️ Route Details

The route covered thousands of kilometers across dense forest tracks, savannah, and remote mountain roads:

  • Yamoussoukro Region: Heat-baked gravel with unpredictable ruts, hidden rocks, and occasional rain storms.
  • Man & Bouaké Loops: Remote and rarely used roads tested navigation, fuel strategy, and lighting systems.
  • Overnight Sections: Fatigue-heavy stretches required calm, focused driving and co-driver endurance across full night runs.

The sheer length of each leg, combined with minimal service intervals, meant that only the most experienced and disciplined crews stood a chance of finishing—let alone winning.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Björn Waldegård & Fred Gallagher (Toyota Celica TCT)

2nd Place: Erwin Weber & Klaus Wicha (Volkswagen Golf GTI 16V)

3rd Place: Patrick Tauziac & Claude Papin (Mitsubishi Galant)

Waldegård’s calm control and mechanical sympathy once again paid off—securing another Safari-region win and reaffirming his title as the king of African endurance rallying.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Toyota Celica TCT: RWD, turbocharged, and built for toughness—not the fastest, but unmatched in long-distance rally survival.
  • Volkswagen Golf GTI 16V: Lightweight and fuel-efficient with excellent balance on degraded gravel tracks.
  • Mitsubishi Galant: Reliable and surprisingly quick—emerging as a competitive platform for privateer teams in Africa.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Extreme Distances: Stages often stretched over 300 km with little service support—pushing man and machine alike.
  • Environmental Hazards: Wildlife, dust storms, and water crossings were as threatening as the rally itself.
  • Driver Focus: Fatigue management and maintaining steady pace without overdriving was the key to reaching the finish.

The 1986 Rallye Côte d’Ivoire was not about spectacle—it was about survival. And as ever, Björn Waldegård showed that in Africa, experience and patience were the ultimate winning traits.

events.title: 1986 Lombard RAC Rally (Great Britain)
events.bio: Timo Salonen closed the Group B era with a measured and decisive win on the muddy stages of Britain, mastering the fog, forests, and fatigue in his final rally with the Peugeot 205 T16.
events.details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1986 Lombard RAC Rally (Great Britain)

Date: November 23–26, 1986

Start Location: Nottingham, England

Finish Location: Chester, England

Total Distance: ~780 km of special stages

Surface: Gravel

The 1986 RAC Rally brought the curtain down on the Group B era in style and mud. Timo Salonen delivered a composed, calculated drive through Britain’s forests, where unpredictable weather, slick surfaces, and restricted recce rules made survival an art form. With Peugeot’s withdrawal from rallying imminent, Salonen gave the 205 T16 a triumphant send-off in one of rally’s most iconic and challenging events.

🗺️ Route Details

The RAC featured over 60 special stages through forests and military grounds, all without pacenotes:

  • Grizedale and Kielder: Long forest stages with slippery gravel and treacherous tree-lined paths.
  • Clocaenog and Hafren: Welsh classics mixing fog, fast crests, and rain-slicked corners with no room for error.
  • Military Zones: Complex night loops with no prior recce—only tulip roadbooks and tight timing.

British weather added to the drama, as fog, rain, and ice turned already treacherous roads into rallying minefields. Driver instinct, co-driver precision, and car reliability determined the podium.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Timo Salonen & Seppo Harjanne (Peugeot 205 T16)

2nd Place: Malcolm Wilson & Nigel Harris (Ford RS200)

3rd Place: Kalle Grundel & Peter Diekmann (Ford RS200)

Salonen’s win was a quiet masterclass—his ability to read the terrain and preserve the car in such hostile conditions made the difference. The Group B era ended with a display of composure over chaos.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Peugeot 205 T16: A final outing for the all-conquering machine—proven, reliable, and fast even as the Group B chapter closed.
  • Ford RS200: Showed serious pace on British soil—compact, quick, and more at home in the RAC than previous events.
  • Lancia Delta S4: Present but plagued by inconsistency and setup challenges in the slippery forests.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • No Pacenotes: Crews relied only on roadbooks—making co-driver timing and memory critical.
  • Variable Conditions: Fog, rain, ice, and deep ruts made every stage unique and every tire choice a gamble.
  • Mechanical Preservation: With over 60 short stages, even minor damage could add up quickly—drivers had to balance pace and caution.

The 1986 RAC Rally gave Group B a muddy, dramatic farewell—and Salonen, ever the calm force, brought the 205 T16 home on top one last time.

events.title: 1986 Paris–Dakar Rally (France–Algeria–Niger–Mali–Senegal)
events.bio: René Metge and Dominique Lemoyne delivered Porsche its historic Dakar win in the advanced 959, conquering 15,000 km of brutal terrain and cementing their place in rally-raid legend.
events.details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1986 Paris–Dakar Rally (France–Algeria–Niger–Mali–Senegal)

Date: January 1–22, 1986

Start Location: Versailles, France

Finish Location: Dakar, Senegal

Total Distance: ~15,000 km (with ~3,700 km competitive)

Surface: Gravel and sand

The 1986 Paris–Dakar Rally pushed competitors through some of the harshest terrain on Earth. Over 15,000 kilometers of deserts, savannah, and unmarked tracks demanded endurance and precision. René Metge and Dominique Lemoyne triumphed in Porsche’s all-wheel-drive 959, a technological marvel that married rally speed with survival engineering. The event was overshadowed by tragedy, however, with the deaths of racer Thierry Sabine and four others in a helicopter crash during the race—casting a somber tone over what became one of the most iconic Dakar victories in history.

🗺️ Route Details

The rally’s trans-African path passed through five countries:

  • France: Departed from Versailles with ceremonial stages before transit to Africa.
  • Algeria: Vast dune fields, rocky plateaus, and searing desert heat tested both navigation and mechanical limits.
  • Niger & Mali: Remote, empty expanses with soft sand, mirages, and frequent navigation traps.
  • Senegal: Final stages toward the Atlantic coast featured compact sand and flood plains near Dakar.

The Sahara dominated the middle of the rally, with competitors facing not only natural threats but also fatigue, mechanical failure, and isolation over long liaison sections.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner (Cars): René Metge & Dominique Lemoyne (Porsche 959)

2nd Place: Jacky Ickx & Claude Brasseur (Porsche 959)

3rd Place: Patrick Zaniroli & Jean Da Silva (Mitsubishi Pajero)

Metge’s win marked his third Dakar triumph and gave Porsche its only overall victory in the event, showcasing both the car’s groundbreaking technology and his own desert rally expertise.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Porsche 959: AWD, twin-turbocharged, and designed with Dakar in mind—its durability and traction proved decisive in loose sand and over long distances.
  • Mitsubishi Pajero: Proven and reliable, it offered excellent ground clearance and suspension for African rally conditions.
  • Mercedes G-Wagen (support & privateers): Notable for its toughness—many used them as assistance and backup vehicles.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Extreme Length: Over two weeks of racing across thousands of kilometers demanded unmatched endurance and reliability.
  • Navigation: Errors in compass headings or timing often meant hours lost—or complete disqualification.
  • Fatal Incident: On January 14, race founder Thierry Sabine and four others died in a helicopter crash, casting a shadow over the event's legacy.

The 1986 Paris–Dakar will be remembered both for Porsche’s historic win and the tragic loss of Thierry Sabine—a man who helped shape the event into a global phenomenon. His spirit of adventure continues to define the rally to this day.

events.title: 1986 Hong Kong–Beijing Rally (China)
events.bio: Stig Blomqvist piloted the Audi Quattro A2 to victory in the second running of the Hong Kong–Beijing Rally, navigating China's evolving roadways in a showcase of endurance, diplomacy, and precision.
events.details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1986 Hong Kong–Beijing Rally (China)

Date: September 14–18, 1986

Start Location: Hong Kong

Finish Location: Beijing, China

Total Distance: 835 km of special stages

Surface: Asphalt and gravel

The 1986 Hong Kong–Beijing Rally returned as a high-profile demonstration of international rallying in a rapidly changing China. With roads ranging from polished tarmac to rugged countryside tracks, it was a unique mix of modern infrastructure and rural unpredictability. Stig Blomqvist, a former world champion, showed masterful composure and adaptability in the Audi Quattro A2 to win the event—demonstrating the car’s continued relevance in varied terrain despite the rise of newer Group B machines elsewhere.

🗺️ Route Details

The rally stretched across southeastern China, covering diverse landscapes and logistical challenges:

  • Guangdong Province: Dense urban areas and newly built roadways required tight timing and patience through traffic zones.
  • Hunan and Henan: Rural mountain roads with gravel detours and deep ruts, demanding precise car placement.
  • Final Leg to Beijing: Long, fast transport and competitive sectors with improved surfaces and diplomatic fanfare.

Unlike traditional WRC rounds, this rally was also a symbolic event, blending motorsport with cultural exchange and cross-border cooperation.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Stig Blomqvist & Bruno Berglund (Audi Quattro A2)

2nd Place: Mike Kirkland & David Williamson (Nissan 240RS)

3rd Place: Per Eklund & Claes Billstam (Toyota Celica TCT)

Blomqvist’s precise pace and familiarity with long-distance rallying gave him the edge—his Audi was both powerful and dependable across China’s transitional infrastructure.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Audi Quattro A2: While aging, its proven AWD system and torque delivery gave it a strong edge in mixed conditions.
  • Nissan 240RS: Light, rear-wheel drive endurance car favored by privateers—durable and easy to service on long rallies.
  • Toyota Celica TCT: Known for toughness and balance, the TCT performed well in both rough and smooth sectors.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Political Coordination: Multiple checkpoints and security protocols required close cooperation with local authorities.
  • Route Ambiguity: Limited signage and last-minute detours tested co-driver concentration and adaptability.
  • Vehicle Preservation: Despite its symbolic nature, the rally’s unpredictable surfaces required cautious driving to avoid retirement.

The 1986 Hong Kong–Beijing Rally was a cultural milestone as much as a motorsport event—and Blomqvist’s victory symbolized both skill and diplomacy in motion.

events.title: 1987 Rallye Monte-Carlo (Monaco)
events.bio: Miki Biasion opened the Group A era with a commanding win in the Lancia Delta HF 4WD, mastering Monte Carlo’s icy asphalt to mark a new chapter in rally history.
events.details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1987 Rallye Monte-Carlo (Monaco)

Date: January 17–22, 1987

Start Location: Various European cities

Finish Location: Monte Carlo, Monaco

Total Distance: 742 km of special stages

Surface: Asphalt and snow

The 1987 Rallye Monte-Carlo ushered in the post-Group B era with Group A machinery, and Miki Biasion was the man to beat. Driving the brand-new Lancia Delta HF 4WD, he tamed the unpredictable conditions of the French Alps—blending dry tarmac, black ice, and snowy climbs—to claim a historic win. With the sport reeling from the previous year’s tragedies, Monte Carlo became both a fresh start and a powerful statement from Lancia’s next-generation platform.

🗺️ Route Details

Monte Carlo’s 1987 route featured many classic stages with renewed focus on safety and control:

  • Col de Turini: Still the centerpiece—icy hairpins and cliffside straights lined with cautious spectators.
  • Sisteron–Thoard: High-speed technical stage blending clean tarmac and hidden ice patches.
  • Col de Braus: Narrow switchbacks requiring careful tire selection and patient throttle modulation.

With less power but more balance, Group A cars like the Delta HF 4WD brought a new style of rallying: more control, more strategy, and a focus on precision over pure speed.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Miki Biasion & Tiziano Siviero (Lancia Delta HF 4WD)

2nd Place: Bruno Saby & Jean-François Fauchille (Renault 11 Turbo)

3rd Place: François Chatriot & Michel Périn (BMW M3)

Biasion’s calm drive and the Delta’s four-wheel-drive traction proved perfect for the mixed Monte surfaces, establishing Lancia’s dominance from day one of Group A competition.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Lancia Delta HF 4WD: Debut victory for the future WRC powerhouse—four-wheel-drive and turbocharged with improved reliability and chassis control.
  • Renault 11 Turbo: Light, nimble, and quick off the line, especially competitive on tarmac but lacked consistency in mixed grip.
  • BMW M3: Rear-wheel drive made it tricky in snow but formidable on dry stages with sharp handling and balance.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Mixed Surface Mastery: Constant shifts between ice, snow, and dry asphalt forced last-minute tire decisions and on-the-fly driving adjustments.
  • New Regulations: First WRC rally under Group A rules meant teams were still adapting setup and pace expectations.
  • Spectator Expectations: After Group B, fans adjusted to a slower—but more tactical—style of rallying.

The 1987 Rallye Monte-Carlo marked the start of a safer, more calculated era—and Miki Biasion’s win set the tone for Lancia’s dominance in years to come.

events.title: 1987 International Swedish Rally (Sweden)
events.bio: Hannu Mikkola showed that experience and quattro traction still mattered by winning the snow-covered Swedish Rally in the heavier but powerful Audi 200 Quattro.
events.details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1987 International Swedish Rally (Sweden)

Date: February 13–15, 1987

Start Location: Karlstad, Sweden

Finish Location: Karlstad, Sweden

Total Distance: 549 km of special stages

Surface: Snow and ice

The 1987 Swedish Rally delivered classic winter rallying—snowbanks, studded tires, and flat-out commitment in slippery Scandinavian forests. Hannu Mikkola, a veteran of the ice, put his expertise to good use by guiding the bulky but stable Audi 200 Quattro to a surprising victory. It was a testament to quattro technology and Mikkola’s finesse that the older Audi was able to outlast the newer Group A field in such treacherous conditions.

🗺️ Route Details

Sweden’s snowbound stages offered classic conditions, with narrow, fast-flowing routes lined with snowbanks:

  • Hagfors and Torsby: Frozen tracks with technical sections requiring rhythm and commitment.
  • Lysvik and Fredriksberg: Long, sweeping routes favoring AWD traction and confident late braking into corners.
  • Night Stages: Limited visibility, deep ruts, and freezing temps pushed drivers into full concentration mode.

Weather remained cold and consistent throughout the rally, with deep snow allowing drivers to lean on banks—but punishing anyone who pushed too far.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Hannu Mikkola & Arne Hertz (Audi 200 Quattro)

2nd Place: Markku Alén & Ilkka Kivimäki (Lancia Delta HF 4WD)

3rd Place: Kalle Grundel & Peter Diekmann (Ford Sierra XR4x4)

Mikkola’s win was a nod to rally experience, steady hands, and Audi’s famed quattro advantage—even as newer, lighter Group A cars were beginning to take over the sport.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Audi 200 Quattro: Large and less agile than its rivals, but with excellent traction and reliability on snowy terrain.
  • Lancia Delta HF 4WD: Quick and light, but not yet as refined as it would become—still a major threat in all conditions.
  • Ford Sierra XR4x4: New entry from Ford with promising AWD capability and good balance on snow stages.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Snowbank Strategy: Drivers used them to carry more speed—but contact at the wrong angle could mean disaster.
  • Studded Tire Tactics: Choosing the right compound and managing stud wear was key over repeated stage use.
  • Weight vs. Control: Mikkola proved that even a heavier car could win with the right setup and patience.

The 1987 Swedish Rally was a showcase of skill over raw performance—Hannu Mikkola’s win in an aging Audi was a masterclass in snow rallying.

events.title: 1987 Rallye de Portugal (Portugal)
events.bio: Miki Biasion showcased the Lancia Delta HF 4WD’s superiority across Portugal’s gravel and tarmac roads, taking a confident win and further establishing Lancia’s Group A dominance.
events.details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1987 Rallye de Portugal (Portugal)

Date: March 4–7, 1987

Start Location: Estoril, Portugal

Finish Location: Estoril, Portugal

Total Distance: 684 km of special stages

Surface: Gravel and tarmac

The 1987 Rallye de Portugal was a commanding victory for Miki Biasion, who expertly handled the mixed-surface stages and heavy fan presence to bring home another win for Lancia. With the Group A Lancia Delta HF 4WD hitting its stride, Biasion capitalized on its balance and traction in both dusty gravel and slick tarmac conditions—outdriving the competition across classic Portuguese terrain.

🗺️ Route Details

Portugal’s stages provided a mix of fast gravel and asphalt segments, often packed with passionate and unpredictable spectators:

  • Arganil: Legendary gravel stage—dusty, fast, and tight through mountain ridges.
  • Lousã and Fafe: Known for big jumps, wide-angle corners, and massive crowds lining every turn.
  • Sintra Tarmac Stages: Slick, technical asphalt segments requiring total precision and careful tire management.

Crowd control remained a concern throughout the event, but improved from previous years. Biasion's control under pressure won praise from fans and officials alike.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Miki Biasion & Tiziano Siviero (Lancia Delta HF 4WD)

2nd Place: Juha Kankkunen & Juha Piironen (Mazda 323 4WD)

3rd Place: Markku Alén & Ilkka Kivimäki (Lancia Delta HF 4WD)

Biasion’s measured drive and the Delta’s reliable handling gave Lancia another edge, as rival teams struggled to keep up with the pace across surface changes.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Lancia Delta HF 4WD: Group A’s rising star—balanced, agile, and capable across varying surfaces and conditions.
  • Mazda 323 4WD: Light and quick with solid reliability, the 323 was emerging as a serious Group A competitor.
  • Ford Sierra RS Cosworth: Fast on tarmac but less consistent on gravel—rear-wheel drive limitations showed in slippery conditions.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Surface Transitions: Gravel to tarmac changes demanded constant pace adjustment and split tire strategies.
  • Fan Density: Portugal’s iconic stages were lined with thousands—forcing focus and discipline through chaotic corridors.
  • Weather Swings: Damp coastal air and dusty inland stages made traction an evolving puzzle throughout the rally.

Biasion’s triumph in Portugal signaled that Lancia had fully adapted to the Group A landscape—and that the Delta HF 4WD was here to dominate it.

events.title: 1987 Safari Rally (Kenya)
events.bio: Hannu Mikkola added another Safari win to his résumé, expertly handling the punishing African terrain in the Audi 200 Quattro to outlast the competition in one of the WRC’s most grueling events.
events.details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1987 Safari Rally (Kenya)

Date: April 9–13, 1987

Start Location: Nairobi, Kenya

Finish Location: Nairobi, Kenya

Total Distance: 4,100 km

Surface: Gravel

The 1987 Safari Rally reaffirmed its reputation as the WRC’s ultimate test of endurance and vehicle preservation. Hannu Mikkola and Arne Hertz navigated vast dust clouds, mechanical hazards, and unpredictable African weather to guide their Audi 200 Quattro to victory. In a year that saw Group A solidify its place in the championship, Mikkola proved that experience and reliability were the keys to conquering the savannah.

🗺️ Route Details

The Safari’s marathon stages covered rough gravel, deep water crossings, and long transport sections with minimal service:

  • Amboseli Plains: Flat, fast, and dusty stretches with wildlife hazards and blinding visibility.
  • Mount Kenya Region: Rocky ascents and muddy descents with heavy vegetation and elevation changes.
  • Lake Naivasha & Nakuru: Deep ruts and water-logged segments that threatened cooling systems and electronics.

Teams relied heavily on local assistance crews and strategic pacing to minimize breakdowns across Kenya’s punishing terrain.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Hannu Mikkola & Arne Hertz (Audi 200 Quattro)

2nd Place: Mike Kirkland & David Williamson (Nissan 240RS)

3rd Place: Shekhar Mehta & Yvonne Mehta (Peugeot 504 Pickup)

Mikkola’s win marked his final WRC victory—an emotional and fitting result for one of rally’s all-time greats on one of the sport’s most legendary events.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Audi 200 Quattro: Long and heavy, but extremely stable and durable—ideal for long-distance rally survival.
  • Nissan 240RS: Rear-wheel-drive, but proven tough in harsh African conditions—simple and reliable under pressure.
  • Peugeot 504 Pickup: Rugged and versatile, the Mehtas’ machine demonstrated that endurance and familiarity with local terrain could still challenge factory-backed efforts.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Extreme Distances: Some stages stretched over 300 km with almost no external support.
  • Weather Hazards: Torrential rain, deep water crossings, and dust storms could appear without warning.
  • Mechanical Preservation: Suspension and cooling systems were constantly at risk—driving too hard almost guaranteed retirement.

The 1987 Safari Rally proved once again that the toughest car doesn’t always win—the smartest driver does. Hannu Mikkola’s triumph was a masterclass in rally endurance and discipline.

events.title: 1987 Tour de Corse – Rallye de France (Corsica)
events.bio: Bruno Saby tamed the narrow, twisting tarmac of Corsica to win the Tour de Corse in the Lancia Delta HF 4WD, showing finesse and control in one of rallying’s most demanding asphalt events.
events.details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1987 Tour de Corse – Rallye de France (Corsica)

Date: May 8–10, 1987

Start Location: Ajaccio, Corsica

Finish Location: Ajaccio, Corsica

Total Distance: 1,032 km of special stages

Surface: Asphalt

The 1987 Tour de Corse demanded surgical precision across thousands of corners on Corsica’s unforgiving mountain tarmac. Bruno Saby, one of France’s top asphalt specialists, delivered a masterful performance in the Lancia Delta HF 4WD. With narrow roads, no run-off, and constant steering input required, the rally rewarded smoothness and mental endurance. Saby held off strong competition in a tightly contested event that proved Group A cars could shine on pure tarmac just as well as their monstrous predecessors.

🗺️ Route Details

Corsica’s stages offered elevation, complexity, and minimal margin for error:

  • Vico–Sagliolo: Fast and technical with cambered edges and cliffside drop-offs.
  • Palneca–Zicavo: Endless switchbacks and tight compression zones that tested brakes and balance.
  • Sartène–Propriano: Smooth yet deceptive—rewarded precision and punished hesitation.

Heat and wear were major factors, with tire degradation and brake fade a constant concern through the event’s long, twisty loops.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Bruno Saby & Jean-François Fauchille (Lancia Delta HF 4WD)

2nd Place: François Chatriot & Michel Périn (BMW M3)

3rd Place: Yves Loubet & Jean-Marc Andrié (Lancia Delta HF 4WD)

Saby’s victory highlighted the Delta’s versatility on all surfaces, and Corsica cemented his status as one of rallying’s top tarmac specialists.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Lancia Delta HF 4WD: Proved adaptable even on pure asphalt with strong grip, agile steering, and exceptional traction out of tight corners.
  • BMW M3: Rear-wheel drive tarmac weapon—lighter and more precise in fast sections but lacked traction on tighter climbs.
  • Renault 11 Turbo: Competitive in early stages but fell off pace in longer loops due to heat and mechanical stress.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Endless Corners: Nearly every stage featured constant direction changes—perfect pacenotes were critical.
  • Brake Management: Fade became a major issue on long descents—teams had to carefully balance speed and heat.
  • Mental Stamina: The technical demands of Corsica required intense focus over hours of precision driving.

The 1987 Tour de Corse was a rally of concentration and composure—Bruno Saby’s victory proved that pure driving finesse still ruled on the twisting roads of Corsica.

events.title: 1987 Acropolis Rally (Greece)
events.bio: Juha Kankkunen mastered the brutal heat and rocky terrain of Greece to take victory in the Lancia Delta HF 4WD, reinforcing his title bid and the Delta’s toughness in extreme conditions.
events.details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1987 Acropolis Rally (Greece)

Date: June 1–4, 1987

Start Location: Athens, Greece

Finish Location: Athens, Greece

Total Distance: 849 km of special stages

Surface: Gravel

The 1987 Acropolis Rally once again delivered dust, destruction, and drama as teams tackled the infamous Greek mountains. Juha Kankkunen handled the punishing terrain with confidence and precision, guiding the Lancia Delta HF 4WD through rock-strewn tracks and oppressive heat to take a commanding victory. His win marked another notch in the Delta’s growing Group A legacy and solidified his position as a leading title contender.

🗺️ Route Details

The Acropolis Rally’s stages stretched through dry, rocky, and mountainous terrain under searing heat:

  • Mount Parnassus: Dusty mountain climbs and descents with sharp switchbacks and exposed boulders.
  • Kalambaka Region: Rough forest roads and high-speed straights riddled with embedded rock hazards.
  • Lamia Loops: Bone-jarring ruts and loose gravel required total mechanical sympathy and car control.

Temperatures soared into the 40s Celsius, challenging both cars and crews as the rally pushed reliability to its limits.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Juha Kankkunen & Juha Piironen (Lancia Delta HF 4WD)

2nd Place: Miki Biasion & Tiziano Siviero (Lancia Delta HF 4WD)

3rd Place: Yves Loubet & Jean-Marc Andrié (Lancia Delta HF 4WD)

It was a dominant Lancia 1-2-3 finish, proving that the Delta HF 4WD could survive—and thrive—where others broke down.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Lancia Delta HF 4WD: Tough, nimble, and adaptable—its robust suspension and drivetrain excelled on the broken terrain of Greece.
  • Mazda 323 4WD: Fast and reliable but lacked the suspension durability needed for the roughest sectors.
  • Ford Sierra RS Cosworth: Struggled on rocky gravel; quick on smoother stages but too fragile to consistently compete in Greece.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Rough Terrain: Tire punctures and suspension failure were common—conservative pacing was often rewarded.
  • Heat Fatigue: Driver and co-driver endurance played a major role as cockpit temps soared past safe limits.
  • Dust Clouds: Limited visibility in the rear of the running order created overtaking hazards and time losses.

The 1987 Acropolis Rally tested every bolt and every nerve—Kankkunen’s victory was built on experience, strategy, and unwavering composure across Greece’s harshest terrain.

events.title: 1987 Rally New Zealand
events.bio: Franz Wittmann delivered a surprise victory in the Audi 200 Quattro, mastering New Zealand’s flowing gravel roads and scoring a rare win for Audi in the evolving Group A era.
events.details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1987 Rally New Zealand

Date: July 1987

Start Location: Auckland, New Zealand

Finish Location: Auckland, New Zealand

Total Distance: ~500 km of special stages

Surface: Gravel

The 1987 Rally New Zealand delivered smooth gravel roads, sweeping corners, and a major upset. Franz Wittmann, driving the aging Audi 200 Quattro, kept a consistent pace and avoided the mistakes and mechanical issues that plagued more favored teams. His calm approach on New Zealand’s fast and flowing stages earned him his first—and only—WRC win, making him the first Austrian to win a WRC round.

🗺️ Route Details

New Zealand’s world-renowned gravel roads were the star of the show:

  • North Island Forests: Smooth, cambered gravel with a natural rhythm that rewarded confidence and balance.
  • Whangarei Region: Fast-flowing sections with rolling hills and blind crests—mistakes here were costly.
  • Rotorua Loops: Slightly rougher sectors with deeper gravel, requiring good tire strategy and throttle modulation.

Weather was relatively dry, giving drivers optimal visibility and traction for high-speed performance.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Franz Wittmann & Kurt Nestinger (Audi 200 Quattro)

2nd Place: Markku Alén & Ilkka Kivimäki (Lancia Delta HF 4WD)

3rd Place: Kenneth Eriksson & Peter Diekmann (Volkswagen Golf GTI 16V)

Wittmann’s shock victory made headlines and stood as a testament to the power of steady driving and mechanical reliability on long gravel stages.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Audi 200 Quattro: Long and heavy, but incredibly stable and rugged—ideal for high-speed gravel if well-managed.
  • Lancia Delta HF 4WD: The car to beat in 1987—quick, balanced, but occasionally prone to mechanical issues in longer rallies.
  • Volkswagen Golf GTI 16V: Light and nimble, competitive in tighter sections but lacked top-end speed on open stages.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Consistency Over Speed: Wittmann avoided major risks, relying on rhythm and road-reading rather than raw pace.
  • Gravel Transitions: Maintaining momentum through long-radius bends required exact throttle input and minimal correction.
  • Underdog Triumph: The rally proved that with smart driving and mechanical sympathy, even older machinery could still win at the top level.

The 1987 Rally New Zealand offered one of the most unexpected—and well-earned—victories of the season, highlighting the enduring value of reliability and rally IQ.

events.title: 1987 1000 Lakes Rally (Finland)
events.bio: Markku Alén thrilled the home crowd with a high-speed masterclass in the Lancia Delta HF 4WD, conquering Finland’s legendary jumps and blind crests for a dominant home win.
events.details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1987 1000 Lakes Rally (Finland)

Date: August 28–30, 1987

Start Location: Jyväskylä, Finland

Finish Location: Jyväskylä, Finland

Total Distance: 416 km of special stages

Surface: Gravel

The 1987 1000 Lakes Rally once again delivered a breathtaking mix of high-speed gravel, technical jumps, and flowing rhythm. Finnish hero Markku Alén rose to the occasion, delivering a flawless performance in the Lancia Delta HF 4WD. With blinding pace over familiar territory, he mastered the crests and corners to claim a convincing win on home soil, to the delight of thousands of rally fans who lined the forest roads of Central Finland.

🗺️ Route Details

Finland’s iconic stages featured flat-out confidence driving and total commitment:

  • Ouninpohja: The ultimate driver’s stage—full of jumps, long straights, and hidden crests demanding trust in pacenotes.
  • Laukaa: Flowing rhythm-based route with loose gravel, ideal for cars with good suspension travel and precise steering.
  • Ruuhimäki: Known for its massive final-stage jump and fast finish—both a fan favorite and a setup challenge.

Dry weather allowed for clean visibility and optimal grip across the event, encouraging maximum-attack driving throughout.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Markku Alén & Ilkka Kivimäki (Lancia Delta HF 4WD)

2nd Place: Juha Kankkunen & Juha Piironen (Mazda 323 4WD)

3rd Place: Hannu Mikkola & Arne Hertz (Audi 200 Quattro)

Alén’s victory was his fifth in Finland and a definitive reminder of his unmatched pace on home soil—made even more meaningful during Lancia’s ongoing Group A dominance.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Lancia Delta HF 4WD: Quick and agile—perfectly suited to the fast, flowing terrain of Finland with excellent suspension dynamics.
  • Mazda 323 4WD: A rising challenger with great balance, reliability, and cornering grip in long gravel stages.
  • Audi 200 Quattro: Stable and consistent, though bulkier—made up ground through durability and experience.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Blind Crests: Memorization and perfect pacenote calling were essential on Finland’s high-speed jumps and corners.
  • Air Time Management: Improper jump landings could unsettle the car and ruin stage rhythm or worse—end a rally early.
  • Local Pressure: Finnish drivers were expected to perform flawlessly on home ground—Alén delivered in style.

The 1987 1000 Lakes Rally was a celebration of speed, spectacle, and national pride—Alén’s dominant drive stood tall as one of the season’s finest displays of Group A skill.

events.title: 1987 Rallye Sanremo (Italy)
events.bio: Didier Auriol took a breakthrough victory in the Ford Sierra XR4x4 at Sanremo, but the event was later removed from the championship standings due to irregularities in scrutineering procedures.
events.details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1987 Rallye Sanremo (Italy)

Date: October 18–22, 1987

Start Location: Sanremo, Italy

Finish Location: Sanremo, Italy

Total Distance: 391 km of special stages

Surface: Mixed (gravel and asphalt)

The 1987 Rallye Sanremo was meant to be a pivotal moment for rising French talent Didier Auriol, who claimed an emotional first victory in the Ford Sierra XR4x4. The rally’s technical stages transitioned from rough gravel to coastal asphalt, making setup and tire choice critical. However, despite the competitive spectacle, the event was later annulled by the FIA due to procedural violations in technical inspection, rendering all results unofficial and excluding it from the championship calendar.

🗺️ Route Details

Sanremo’s varied terrain combined fast gravel sectors with tight tarmac switchbacks in the Ligurian hills:

  • Andagna–Bajardo: A twisty gravel loop through steep hillside roads with rough surface conditions.
  • Colle Langan: Fast tarmac section requiring early braking discipline and tire management.
  • Monte Ceppo: Classic mixed-surface challenge that required precise transitions and adaptable setups.

Weather remained dry but cool, which helped teams optimize setups across both surfaces—but uncertainty over post-event results ultimately overshadowed the rally’s technical accomplishments.

🏆 Results

Event excluded from WRC standings. Results declared unofficial by FIA.

Original 1st Place (annulled): Didier Auriol & Bernard Occelli (Ford Sierra XR4x4)

2nd Place: Miki Biasion & Tiziano Siviero (Lancia Delta HF 4WD)

3rd Place: Fabrizio Tabaton & Luciano Tedeschini (Lancia Delta HF 4WD)

Although Auriol’s drive impressed fans and media alike, the FIA’s exclusion of the event from the official WRC standings left his achievement in Sanremo without championship points.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Ford Sierra XR4x4: AWD tarmac-capable car with growing potential—Auriol’s win helped elevate its reputation despite the annulment.
  • Lancia Delta HF 4WD: Quick and reliable, but struggled slightly on some of the rougher gravel stages.
  • Renault 11 Turbo: Still competitive on shorter asphalt sections, but aging against Group A rivals.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Surface Transitions: Crews had to constantly adapt from gravel to tarmac—incorrect setup timing could cost crucial seconds.
  • Technical Scrutiny: FIA later ruled procedural violations in scrutineering invalidated the event’s official status.
  • Morale Impact: Teams and drivers were left frustrated by the lack of clarity and post-event politics overshadowing performances.

Despite being excluded from the WRC, the 1987 Sanremo Rally marked a turning point in Didier Auriol’s career and remains a notable—if unofficial—moment in rally history.

events.title: 1987 Rallye Côte d’Ivoire (Ivory Coast)
events.bio: Yves Loubet claimed a major career win in the grueling Ivorian rally, surviving punishing African terrain in his Lancia Delta HF 4WD during this drivers-only WRC round.
events.details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1987 Rallye Côte d’Ivoire (Ivory Coast)

Date: November 1987

Start Location: Abidjan, Ivory Coast

Finish Location: Abidjan, Ivory Coast

Total Distance: ~4,000 km

Surface: Gravel

The 1987 Rallye Côte d’Ivoire remained one of the WRC’s most brutal endurance events. Held as a drivers’ championship-only round, the rally challenged competitors with extreme distances, limited service, and oppressive heat. Yves Loubet and Jean-Michel Arbiolet delivered a calculated and consistent performance to take the win in their Lancia Delta HF 4WD, surviving mechanical stress and navigation difficulties to stand atop the podium in Africa.

🗺️ Route Details

The route traversed remote savannah, dense jungle roads, and fast gravel tracks across the interior of Côte d’Ivoire:

  • Yamoussoukro Loops: Long, technical stages featuring deep ruts, dense brush, and surprise washouts.
  • Man Region: Fast, open plains with wildlife hazards and heat-strained engine loads.
  • Night Sections: Fatigue-heavy legs requiring intense concentration and flawless timing from both driver and co-driver.

Minimal service opportunities and unpredictable road conditions made every kilometer a risk—survival took precedence over flat-out speed.

🏆 Results

Drivers-only round – no manufacturers' points awarded

Overall Winner: Yves Loubet & Jean-Michel Arbiolet (Lancia Delta HF 4WD)

2nd Place: Erwin Weber & Manfred Hiemer (Volkswagen Golf GTI 16V)

3rd Place: Alain Ambrosino & Jean-Pierre Bousquet (Toyota Celica TCT)

Loubet’s win cemented his name among endurance rally greats—he managed risk, mechanical sympathy, and heat better than anyone across the multi-day marathon.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Lancia Delta HF 4WD: Adapted for endurance with reinforced suspension and cooling—strong performance under extreme pressure.
  • Volkswagen Golf GTI 16V: A durable and nimble contender with excellent fuel economy and heat resistance.
  • Toyota Celica TCT: Proven workhorse in African conditions—robust, consistent, and easy to repair mid-stage.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Exhaustive Distance: With over 4,000 km covered, pacing and mechanical preservation were crucial for survival.
  • Service Scarcity: Long stretches between support meant drivers often had to manage small issues alone.
  • Environmental Hazards: Dust, dehydration, and engine heat-related failures were constant threats across the event.

The 1987 Rallye Côte d’Ivoire demanded patience, mechanical empathy, and precise coordination. Yves Loubet’s victory was a study in how to conquer Africa’s toughest terrain without needing to be the fastest man on every stage.

events.title: 1987 Lombard RAC Rally (Great Britain)
events.bio: Juha Kankkunen clinched the 1987 World Rally Championship by mastering Britain’s foggy forests in his Lancia Delta HF 4WD, securing both the rally win and the drivers' title.
events.details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1987 Lombard RAC Rally (Great Britain)

Date: November 22–26, 1987

Start Location: Chester, England

Finish Location: Chester, England

Total Distance: 316 km of special stages

Surface: Gravel

The 1987 RAC Rally served as the dramatic final chapter in a season-long title fight between Juha Kankkunen and Markku Alén. With wet gravel, dense fog, and dozens of forest stages across Wales, Kankkunen kept a cool head and consistent pace in his Lancia Delta HF 4WD to take the victory—and with it, his second world championship. The RAC’s unique no-recce format and ever-changing British weather added an extra layer of difficulty to an already pressure-filled finale.

🗺️ Route Details

The rally featured over 50 timed stages through British forests and private estates, many of which were driven blind:

  • Kielder Forest: Long and punishing stages with fast straights and minimal margin for error in tight tree-lined sections.
  • Clocaenog and Dyfi: Welsh forest classics with wet gravel, mist, and blind crests—driver instinct was critical.
  • Military Areas: Short, high-risk night stages that offered little recovery room from even minor mistakes.

The event’s traditional lack of pacenotes required exceptional co-driver timing and map-reading precision under immense pressure.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Juha Kankkunen & Juha Piironen (Lancia Delta HF 4WD)

2nd Place: Hannu Mikkola & Arne Hertz (Mazda 323 4WD)

3rd Place: Jimmy McRae & Ian Grindrod (Ford Sierra RS Cosworth)

Kankkunen’s triumph in the RAC sealed both the rally win and the 1987 drivers’ championship, marking Lancia’s growing dynasty in the Group A era.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Lancia Delta HF 4WD: The most complete Group A car of the season—capable in all conditions, including Britain's wet and slippery gravel.
  • Mazda 323 4WD: Fast and durable, especially in longer stages—Mikkola extracted its full potential through experience and measured pace.
  • Ford Sierra RS Cosworth: Rear-wheel drive made it a handful in the wet, but strong on cleaner gravel and tarmac-linked sections.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • No Pacenotes: RAC tradition forced crews to rely on roadbooks and rapid in-stage communication.
  • Fog and Rain: Classic British weather created poor visibility and traction inconsistencies from stage to stage.
  • Title Pressure: Kankkunen had to balance outright speed with the need to avoid mistakes in a high-stakes finale.

The 1987 Lombard RAC Rally capped a fiercely contested season—Kankkunen’s clinical win in the forests of Britain delivered him a second world crown and secured Lancia’s hold on the new era of rallying.

events.title: 1987 Paris–Dakar Rally (France–Algeria–Niger–Mali–Senegal)
events.bio: Ari Vatanen and Bernard Giroux triumphed in the grueling 1987 Paris–Dakar, driving the heavily modified Peugeot 205 T16 Grand Raid across nearly 13,000 km of desert and savannah in a stunning return to rally-raid for both driver and manufacturer.
events.details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1987 Paris–Dakar Rally (France–Algeria–Niger–Mali–Senegal)

Date: January 1–22, 1987

Start Location: Paris, France

Finish Location: Dakar, Senegal

Total Distance: ~13,000 km (total route)

Surface: Gravel and sand

The 1987 Paris–Dakar marked a historic comeback for both Ari Vatanen and Peugeot. With rallying roots firmly planted in Group B, Vatanen piloted the formidable Peugeot 205 T16 Grand Raid through desert dunes, rocky plains, and savannah expanses in a brutal test of endurance and navigation. Overcoming setbacks and mechanical threats, he secured his first Dakar win and Peugeot’s maiden victory in the world’s toughest rally-raid event.

🗺️ Route Details

The route spanned five countries, crossing varied and unforgiving terrain:

  • France: Ceremonial start in Paris followed by transport to North Africa.
  • Algeria: Mountain passes and gravel highlands with increasing desert exposure.
  • Niger & Mali: Endless dune fields, navigation traps, and heat-exhausting liaisons through the Sahara.
  • Senegal: Faster gravel sectors leading to the final dash along the Atlantic coast to Dakar’s famous podium.

Navigation challenges and limited support across the desert made mechanical preservation and co-driver accuracy as crucial as driving speed.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Ari Vatanen & Bernard Giroux (Peugeot 205 T16 Grand Raid)

2nd Place: Shekhar Mehta & Yvonne Mehta (Nissan 240RS)

3rd Place: Patrick Tambay & Dominique Lemoyne (Peugeot 205 T16 Grand Raid)

Vatanen’s victory was a redemption arc—just one year after his career-threatening crash in Argentina, he returned with trademark aggression and the experience to survive Dakar’s endless obstacles.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Peugeot 205 T16 Grand Raid: Modified for Dakar with extended range, improved suspension, and increased durability—blending rally DNA with long-haul survival features.
  • Nissan 240RS: Proven endurance machine with simplicity and strength on its side—competitive in rougher sections.
  • Mitsubishi Pajero: A reliable challenger, still rising in the Dakar scene, but outpaced by Peugeot’s advanced development.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Desert Navigation: Vast open terrain meant compass-based course corrections and pacenote improvisation were constant.
  • Fatigue and Isolation: Multiple days in remote wilderness with little outside communication—co-driver endurance was critical.
  • Mechanical Risk: Tire failures, drivetrain wear, and fuel logistics were ever-present threats across every stage.

The 1987 Paris–Dakar was a turning point—Group B power met desert adaptation, and Ari Vatanen etched his name into rally-raid legend in a defining performance for both man and machine.

events.title: 1988 Rallye Monte-Carlo (Monaco)
events.bio: Bruno Saby opened the 1988 WRC season with a calculated and confident win in Monte Carlo, conquering snow-dusted tarmac in his Lancia Delta HF 4WD and leading a strong start for Lancia’s title defense.
events.details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1988 Rallye Monte-Carlo (Monaco)

Date: January 23–28, 1988

Start Location: Multiple European cities (concentration run)

Finish Location: Monte Carlo, Monaco

Total Distance: 670 km of special stages

Surface: Asphalt and snow

The 1988 Monte Carlo Rally maintained its legendary mix of treacherous conditions and scenic danger. Bruno Saby, driving the Lancia Delta HF 4WD, maintained pace and poise through narrow Alpine passes, battling snow, black ice, and tarmac changes. Unlike past flat-out Monte wins, this one was built on tire management, calm decision-making, and avoiding disaster across unpredictable mountain terrain. Saby’s victory helped kick off Lancia’s dominant season in fine form.

🗺️ Route Details

Classic stages and weather chaos defined Monte Carlo's ever-unpredictable route:

  • Col de Turini: Iconic, narrow climb featuring ice-lined corners and steep drop-offs—perfectly suited for four-wheel drive advantage.
  • St. Auban–Sigale: Fast, tarmac-heavy stage with mixed traction zones and tire gamble consequences.
  • Col de Braus: Sharp switchbacks with shifting grip—one mistake could cost entire stages.

Monte Carlo 1988 was marked by inconsistent snowfall, creating dramatic differences in grip across even single stages—further increasing the challenge of tire choice and pace notes.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Bruno Saby & Jean-François Fauchille (Lancia Delta HF 4WD)

2nd Place: Miki Biasion & Tiziano Siviero (Lancia Delta HF 4WD)

3rd Place: Didier Auriol & Bernard Occelli (Ford Sierra RS Cosworth 4x4)

Saby’s win demonstrated the value of consistency over aggression, and gave Lancia a double-podium opening to the season.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Lancia Delta HF 4WD: A proven performer in mixed conditions—agile and sure-footed with excellent throttle control on icy tarmac.
  • Ford Sierra RS Cosworth 4x4: New to four-wheel drive and still developing—showed strong pace in the hands of rising star Didier Auriol.
  • BMW M3: Rear-wheel drive meant limited competitiveness on snow, but still quick and precise on clear asphalt stages.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Surface Guessing Game: Conditions changed hourly—correct tire choice was as vital as pace.
  • Night Stages: Visibility on twisty cliffside roads tested nerves and lighting systems under pressure.
  • Team Strategy: Lancia’s coordination of support crews and pace management made the difference in surviving the worst of the Alpine terrain.

The 1988 Monte Carlo Rally emphasized smart driving over raw aggression—Bruno Saby delivered a steady, unshaken run that reflected maturity and mastery of winter rallying strategy.

events.title: 1988 International Swedish Rally (Sweden)
events.bio: Markku Alén dominated Sweden’s snow-covered forests in the Lancia Delta HF 4WD, delivering an aggressive and confident performance that showcased the car’s icy-road mastery.
events.details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1988 International Swedish Rally (Sweden)

Date: February 12–14, 1988

Start Location: Karlstad, Sweden

Finish Location: Karlstad, Sweden

Total Distance: 513 km of special stages

Surface: Snow and ice

The 1988 Swedish Rally lived up to its reputation as one of the fastest events on the WRC calendar, thanks to wide, icy roads and deep snowbanks. Markku Alén took full advantage of the ideal winter conditions, pushing his Lancia Delta HF 4WD to its limits with spectacular sideways action and inch-perfect control. His experience on snow showed through every stage, leading to a commanding victory that further strengthened Lancia’s early-season momentum.

🗺️ Route Details

Sweden’s stages favored high-speed confidence and traction control on frozen terrain:

  • Hagfors–Torsby Loops: Classic fast-flowing roads with well-packed snow and deep snowbanks ideal for bouncing the car into line.
  • Fredriksberg: Long straights and technical corners that rewarded bravery and precision.
  • Lysvik: A fan-favorite loop that blended flat-out sprints with icy braking zones under tree cover.

Studded tires were the order of the day, providing razor-sharp grip in one of the cleanest, coldest Swedish editions in recent years.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Markku Alén & Ilkka Kivimäki (Lancia Delta HF 4WD)

2nd Place: Stig Blomqvist & Bruno Berglund (Ford Sierra RS Cosworth 4x4)

3rd Place: Mikael Ericsson & Claes Billstam (Volkswagen Golf GTI 16V)

Alén’s commanding win reaffirmed his ice-driving credentials and gave Lancia a powerful early lead in the manufacturers’ battle.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Lancia Delta HF 4WD: Studded-tire specialist with precise handling and strong cold-weather reliability—ideal for Sweden’s high-speed runs.
  • Ford Sierra RS Cosworth 4x4: Still developing, but showing promise in the hands of snow veteran Stig Blomqvist.
  • Volkswagen Golf GTI 16V: Nimble and predictable—excellent on compact snow but limited in top speed.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Snowbanks as Tools: Drivers frequently used banks to stabilize slides or shave apexes—too much risk, however, could lead to rollovers.
  • Visibility: Snow spray and low-angle winter light created visibility issues in fast-following sections.
  • Precision Driving: Few events punish even small mistakes like Sweden—Alén’s ability to hold maximum speed through narrow lines was unmatched.

The 1988 Swedish Rally was a snow-sculpted showcase of control and confidence—Alén’s win was not just a display of pace, but of ice-cold rally mastery.

events.title: 1988 Rallye de Portugal (Portugal)
events.bio: Miki Biasion powered through Portugal’s iconic gravel and tarmac stages to take a commanding win, further cementing Lancia’s dominance and his position atop the championship standings.
events.details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1988 Rallye de Portugal (Portugal)

Date: March 1–5, 1988

Start Location: Estoril, Portugal

Finish Location: Estoril, Portugal

Total Distance: 533 km of special stages

Surface: Gravel and tarmac

The 1988 Rallye de Portugal delivered a grueling blend of dusty gravel roads and slick tarmac specials under moody skies. Miki Biasion kept cool under crowd pressure and shifting surfaces to win convincingly in his Lancia Delta HF 4WD. With a balanced pace, reliable car, and perfect tire strategy, Biasion extended his championship lead while surviving the chaos of massive fan turnout and challenging terrain.

🗺️ Route Details

Portugal’s legendary stages featured narrow, hilly runs with unpredictable traction:

  • Arganil: Dusty and technical mountain pass famous for its narrow roads, hairpins, and huge crowds.
  • Lousã: Fast gravel stages with deep ruts and limited visibility in dry conditions.
  • Sintra Tarmac Loops: Tight, scenic asphalt specials that punished poor braking discipline and slick compound miscalculations.

Crowds were again a challenge in 1988, with marshals struggling to control fan positioning—adding tension for top drivers like Biasion during high-speed transitions.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Miki Biasion & Tiziano Siviero (Lancia Delta HF 4WD)

2nd Place: Bruno Saby & Jean-François Fauchille (Lancia Delta HF 4WD)

3rd Place: Didier Auriol & Bernard Occelli (Ford Sierra RS Cosworth 4x4)

Biasion’s win in Portugal was a statement—he could not only match the pace of rivals, but manage the rally’s most chaotic elements better than anyone else on the leaderboard.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Lancia Delta HF 4WD: Once again proved its all-surface versatility—ideal balance of traction and power delivery.
  • Ford Sierra RS Cosworth 4x4: Strong performance on mixed surfaces, especially on tarmac segments, but struggled slightly on rougher gravel sectors.
  • BMW M3: Effective on dry tarmac but lacked the traction and suspension durability needed for Portugal’s rougher gravel routes.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Fan Proximity: Portuguese fans lined the roads dangerously close—requiring constant concentration from drivers on narrow paths.
  • Surface Switching: Alternating gravel and tarmac required tire gambles and fast suspension adjustments between services.
  • Weather Uncertainty: Cloud cover and humidity affected grip and visibility—forcing dynamic pace adjustments mid-stage.

The 1988 Rallye de Portugal was both a technical and psychological battle—Biasion’s victory solidified his role as Lancia’s lead title contender and a master of mixed-condition rallying.

events.title: 1988 Safari Rally (Kenya)
events.bio: Miki Biasion endured Kenya’s brutal landscapes to claim his first Safari Rally victory, combining speed and survival in a punishing test of man and machine.
events.details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1988 Safari Rally (Kenya)

Date: March 31 – April 4, 1988

Start Location: Nairobi, Kenya

Finish Location: Nairobi, Kenya

Total Distance: 3,874 km

Surface: Gravel

The 1988 Safari Rally tested every aspect of endurance rallying, from searing heat and flooded riverbeds to mechanical attrition over endless kilometers. Miki Biasion and Tiziano Siviero delivered a textbook drive, carefully managing their Lancia Delta HF 4WD through treacherous terrain while others faltered. It was Biasion’s first win on African soil—and a critical boost to his world championship campaign.

🗺️ Route Details

The route wound through remote Kenyan regions, with deep water crossings, open plains, and brutal corrugations:

  • Amboseli and Tsavo: Fast, dusty roads with wildlife hazards and variable surface conditions.
  • Mount Kenya Region: Rocky trails and high-elevation climbs taxed suspension and cooling systems.
  • Lakes Naivasha & Baringo: Mud traps and flash-flood-prone segments made timing unpredictable and risk management essential.

Crews faced relentless fatigue, mechanical breakdowns, and unpredictable weather—only the smartest and most reliable contenders made it to Nairobi intact.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Miki Biasion & Tiziano Siviero (Lancia Delta HF 4WD)

2nd Place: Markku Alén & Ilkka Kivimäki (Lancia Delta HF 4WD)

3rd Place: Mike Kirkland & David Williamson (Nissan 200SX)

Lancia’s 1–2 finish marked a major triumph in Group A’s evolution—the Delta HF 4WD proving it could withstand even the world’s harshest rally.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Lancia Delta HF 4WD: Tuned specifically for Safari with added air filtration, heavy-duty suspension, and reinforced components—it proved both fast and durable.
  • Nissan 200SX: A sturdy, well-balanced car built for endurance—Kirkland’s local experience helped the Nissan stay in the fight.
  • Toyota Celica TCT: Quick but fragile in 1988—several contenders were forced to retire due to mechanical failure or terrain-related damage.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Navigation: Crews relied on maps and landmarks—getting lost was often more costly than driving slowly.
  • Wildlife & Terrain: Encounters with zebras, elephants, and deep ruts were part of the daily risk matrix.
  • Mechanical Fatigue: The rough conditions punished gearboxes, differentials, and cooling systems over long stages.

The 1988 Safari Rally rewarded balance and composure—Biasion’s triumph was not only about speed but discipline, marking one of the most important wins of his title-winning season.

events.title: 1988 Tour de Corse – Rallye de France (Corsica)
events.bio: Didier Auriol earned his first WRC victory in commanding fashion on the torturous asphalt of Corsica, mastering the island’s relentless corners in the Ford Sierra RS Cosworth.
events.details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1988 Tour de Corse – Rallye de France (Corsica)

Date: May 5–7, 1988

Start Location: Ajaccio, Corsica

Finish Location: Ajaccio, Corsica

Total Distance: 1,010 km of special stages

Surface: Asphalt

The 1988 Tour de Corse tested every aspect of asphalt rallying—precision, stamina, and commitment. Didier Auriol, in just his second season at the WRC’s top level, delivered a flawless performance in the Ford Sierra RS Cosworth. Known for its unending corners and narrow cliffside routes, Corsica rewarded Auriol’s technical finesse and tire strategy, giving him his maiden win and announcing his arrival among rally’s elite.

🗺️ Route Details

Corsica’s tarmac maze challenged both drivers and co-drivers with its relentless pace and minimal margin for error:

  • Vico–Sagliolo: Fast but narrow descent with blind corners and unforgiving drop-offs.
  • Zicavo–Aullène: Tight mountain switchbacks where car placement and braking precision made all the difference.
  • Sartène–Propriano: Classic Corsican rhythm stage—flowing tarmac with undulating elevation changes and deceptive grip.

With warm spring weather and clean asphalt, the rally rewarded drivers who could attack with confidence while preserving tires and brakes over long loops.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Didier Auriol & Bernard Occelli (Ford Sierra RS Cosworth)

2nd Place: Bruno Saby & Jean-François Fauchille (Lancia Delta HF 4WD)

3rd Place: François Chatriot & Michel Périn (BMW M3)

Auriol’s victory made him the first Frenchman to win Corsica since Jean Ragnotti, thrilling local fans and proving that the Sierra—despite its rear-wheel-drive layout—could still win on the right surface in the right hands.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Ford Sierra RS Cosworth: Rear-wheel-drive, but exceptionally fast on dry tarmac—required absolute commitment and finesse to stay ahead.
  • Lancia Delta HF 4WD: More forgiving in tighter sections, but slightly less agile on fast flowing asphalt stages.
  • BMW M3: Perfectly balanced chassis and responsive handling—one of the most competitive RWD cars on tarmac rallies.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Unending Corners: Drivers faced thousands of bends per day—mental fatigue was as big a threat as mechanical wear.
  • Brake Management: Long downhill sections strained braking systems—especially on rear-wheel-drive cars without engine braking support.
  • Co-driver Precision: Fast and accurate pace notes were vital—any delay could ruin a rhythm-based stage flow.
