Finish Location: Athens, Greece

Total Distance: ~1,200 km (estimated full route)

Competitive Stages: 390.27 km

Surface: Gravel

The Acropolis Rally lived up to its legendary reputation in 2000, delivering scorching temperatures, rocky mountain roads, and relentless punishment to drivers and machinery. Colin McRae thrived in the chaos, pushing his Ford Focus WRC through the dust and destruction to take a hard-fought and well-earned victory — his second of the season and one of the grittiest wins of his career.

🗺️ Route Details

Set in the mountains of central Greece, the Acropolis featured relentless gravel, high heat, and steep ascents. Key stages included:

  • Bauxites: Rough and abrasive with long climbs and descents — frequently caused overheating and tire failures.
  • Thiva: Narrow, technical, and filled with sharp rocks — required perfect line discipline to avoid punctures.
  • Kallithea: Faster but loose-surfaced, with deceptive corners and sudden grip changes.

Dust and heat were constant adversaries — crews frequently dealt with visibility issues and cockpit temperatures exceeding 50°C.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Colin McRae & Nicky Grist (Ford Focus WRC)

2nd Place: Carlos Sainz & Luis Moya (Ford Focus WRC)

3rd Place: Richard Burns & Robert Reid (Subaru Impreza S5 WRC)

McRae and Sainz delivered a commanding 1–2 finish for Ford. Burns mounted a recovery after early issues to claim third, but the day belonged to McRae and his resilience over some of the most punishing stages in the world.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Ford Focus WRC: Strong cooling system and reinforced suspension paid off — both McRae and Sainz avoided major issues despite the conditions.
  • Subaru Impreza S5 WRC: Durable and fast — Burns suffered a minor suspension issue early but finished strong.
  • Peugeot 206 WRC: Lighter and agile, but more vulnerable to damage on rough terrain — mechanical problems sidelined Peugeot’s challenge early.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Extreme Heat: Both cars and crews endured desert-like cabin temperatures — hydration and cooling strategy were critical.
  • Rock Damage: Frequent punctures and broken suspension components plagued the field — smart pace management was key.
  • Driver Fatigue: The slow, brutal nature of stages made mental errors likely — McRae’s concentration and experience made the difference.

The 2000 Acropolis Rally was a true war of attrition — and Colin McRae emerged as the undisputed warrior, proving once again that courage and grit are sometimes the greatest tools in a rally driver’s arsenal.

events.title: 2000 Rally of New Zealand (New Zealand)
events.bio: Marcus Grönholm delivered a world-class performance on New Zealand’s smooth, flowing gravel roads, securing a vital win in his Peugeot 206 WRC to reinforce his WRC title campaign.
events.details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 2000 Rally of New Zealand (New Zealand)

Date: July 13–16, 2000

Start Location: Auckland, New Zealand

Finish Location: Auckland, New Zealand

Total Distance: ~1,400 km (estimated full route)

Competitive Stages: 373.11 km

Surface: Gravel

The 2000 Rally of New Zealand brought classic Kiwi rallying back into the spotlight — ultra-fast gravel roads with impeccable flow and camber. Marcus Grönholm and co-driver Timo Rautiainen put on a clinic of pace and poise, guiding their Peugeot 206 WRC to a decisive victory and taking another critical step toward their eventual world title.

🗺️ Route Details

The rally featured some of the smoothest and most flowing gravel stages in the world, held around the North Island. Key stages included:

  • Te Akau South: A fast, open stage with flowing bends and natural camber that rewarded rhythm and bravery.
  • Maramarua Forest: Narrower and more technical, with loose gravel and tree-lined blind crests.
  • Possum Bourne Sprint: Named after the legendary Kiwi driver — mixed technical corners and elevation changes with enthusiastic local crowds.

Dry conditions and compact gravel allowed for incredibly high average speeds. Confidence in pacenotes and setup was key to making the most of the available grip.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Marcus Grönholm & Timo Rautiainen (Peugeot 206 WRC)

2nd Place: Richard Burns & Robert Reid (Subaru Impreza S6 WRC)

3rd Place: Colin McRae & Nicky Grist (Ford Focus WRC)

Grönholm built a lead early and defended it masterfully as Burns tried to close the gap. McRae pushed hard but couldn’t match the leaders’ pace, settling for a solid podium in one of the season’s purest driver’s rallies.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Peugeot 206 WRC: Light and agile — perfect for the sweeping, high-speed roads of New Zealand. Suspension tuning and throttle response were spot-on.
  • Subaru Impreza S6 WRC: Strong on longer, bumpier stretches — great balance and stability through long corners, with Burns extracting every bit of performance.
  • Ford Focus WRC: Well-rounded and responsive — strong braking and consistent performance, but slightly down on outright speed on this terrain.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Corner Rhythm: The ability to stay committed through flowing bends defined the leaders — even small hesitations cost seconds over a stage.
  • High-Speed Precision: With few braking zones, maintaining momentum was crucial — one missed apex could ruin a split time.
  • Local Enthusiasm: Massive turnout and fan presence on stage roads added atmosphere — and occasional risk — to the already intense action.

Grönholm’s win in New Zealand was one of his most commanding of the season, showcasing the ideal pairing of driver talent and car performance on one of rallying’s most beloved stages.

events.title: 2000 Rally Finland (Finland)
events.bio: Marcus Grönholm thrilled the home crowd with a stunning display of speed and confidence, taking victory on the legendary fast gravel roads of Rally Finland and tightening his grip on the 2000 WRC championship.
events.details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 2000 Rally Finland (Finland)

Date: August 17–20, 2000

Start Location: Jyväskylä, Finland

Finish Location: Jyväskylä, Finland

Total Distance: ~1,500 km (estimated full route)

Competitive Stages: 410.18 km

Surface: Gravel

The 2000 Rally Finland delivered exactly what fans expected — blistering pace, huge jumps, and fierce local competition. Marcus Grönholm, racing on home soil, used his intimate knowledge of the Finnish forest stages to secure a dominant win, thrilling the massive crowds and extending his lead in the WRC standings.

🗺️ Route Details

Based in Jyväskylä, the rally’s gravel stages featured wide, cambered roads, flowing crests, and minimal braking zones. Key stages included:

  • Ouninpohja: The crown jewel of Finland — high-speed jumps and blind crests demanding perfect pace note delivery and courage.
  • Lankamaa: Fast and sweeping with deep cuts and loose gravel — punished hesitation and rewarded commitment.
  • Ruuhimäki: Famous for massive final-stage jumps and huge fan attendance.

With dry weather and hard-packed roads, crews had the confidence to push flat-out — leading to some of the highest average stage speeds of the season.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Marcus Grönholm & Timo Rautiainen (Peugeot 206 WRC)

2nd Place: Richard Burns & Robert Reid (Subaru Impreza S6 WRC)

3rd Place: Carlos Sainz & Luis Moya (Ford Focus WRC)

Grönholm led from the start and never looked back, while Burns kept the pressure on but couldn’t close the gap. Sainz brought home another consistent finish for Ford, fending off local specialists.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Peugeot 206 WRC: Light, nimble, and powerful — excelled over crests and through long sweeping corners with flawless balance.
  • Subaru Impreza S6 WRC: Strong engine and great traction — Burns used its stability to stay close on the faster stages.
  • Ford Focus WRC: Balanced and quick, but struggled to match the top two’s raw pace over Finland’s most flowing roads.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • High-Speed Jumps: Maintaining throttle over crests was key — drivers had to commit with limited visibility and full trust in pacenotes.
  • Corner Rhythm: Finland is all about flow — mistakes in rhythm cost precious seconds and shattered confidence.
  • Pressure at Home: Grönholm thrived under expectation, delivering one of his most complete performances of the season.

Grönholm’s Rally Finland victory was a defining moment in his championship season — a fearless, flat-out performance that confirmed his mastery of high-speed gravel and thrilled fans across his homeland.

events.title: 2000 China Rally (China)
events.bio: Possum Bourne returned to the top step of the podium with a commanding win at the 2000 China Rally, expertly navigating the tight, dusty mountain roads in his Subaru Impreza WRX to secure victory in the FIA Asia-Pacific Rally Championship round.
events.details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 2000 China Rally (China)

Date: September 7–9, 2000

Start Location: Shaoguan, Guangdong Province, China

Finish Location: Shaoguan, China

Total Distance: ~1,000 km (estimated full route)

Competitive Stages: 276.26 km

Surface: Gravel

Part of the FIA Asia-Pacific Rally Championship (APRC), the 2000 China Rally featured narrow gravel tracks, humid subtropical weather, and complex mountain stages. Possum Bourne, one of the Southern Hemisphere’s rally greats, took control early and drove smartly to secure a comfortable win for Subaru, reinforcing his status as a dominant force in the APRC.

🗺️ Route Details

The stages were carved into mountainous forest terrain in Guangdong Province. Key characteristics included:

  • Dense Forest Roads: Tight, twisty gravel routes flanked by thick vegetation — pace note accuracy was essential.
  • Elevation Changes: Frequent climbs and descents with sharp braking zones and blind corners.
  • Dust Management: The fine gravel created major visibility challenges, especially for cars running further back.

Localized rainfall prior to the event created unpredictable grip in places, with some sections slippery and others dry and dusty.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Possum Bourne & Mark Stacey (Subaru Impreza WRX)

2nd Place: Karamjit Singh & Allen Oh (Proton Pert)

3rd Place: Yoshio Fujimoto & TBA (Toyota Corolla WRC)

Bourne's experience and discipline kept him ahead throughout. Singh impressed with strong pace in the Proton, while Fujimoto completed the podium despite intermittent mechanical issues.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Subaru Impreza WRX: Rugged and responsive — its traction and torque delivered an ideal balance for China’s technical gravel.
  • Proton Pert: Based on Mitsubishi running gear — strong performance and reliability across the narrow stages.
  • Toyota Corolla WRC: Powerful and quick, but occasionally fragile in the heat and dust of China’s terrain.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Dust and Visibility: Thick airborne gravel dust hung in the air — early road position proved advantageous.
  • Navigation Accuracy: The narrow roads and frequent hairpins demanded near-perfect pace note delivery.
  • Humidity and Heat: Tropical conditions challenged driver stamina and increased mechanical stress — cooling systems were critical.

The China Rally provided a tough test for both man and machine. Possum Bourne’s victory was a testament to his consistency, patience, and mastery of tricky, technical terrain in one of the APRC’s most demanding rounds.

events.title: 2000 Cyprus Rally (Cyprus)
events.bio: Carlos Sainz used his experience and trademark consistency to master the rough and twisty gravel roads of the 2000 Cyprus Rally, claiming his first win of the season and helping Ford stay in the thick of the manufacturers’ title fight.
events.details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 2000 Cyprus Rally (Cyprus)

Date: September 8–10, 2000

Start Location: Limassol, Cyprus

Finish Location: Limassol, Cyprus

Total Distance: ~1,100 km (estimated full route)

Competitive Stages: 348.41 km

Surface: Gravel

The 2000 Cyprus Rally was one of the slowest and roughest on the WRC calendar, with tight, winding mountain tracks and searing Mediterranean heat. Carlos Sainz showed his class and composure on the technical terrain, using patience and mechanical sympathy to outlast rivals and bring home a valuable victory for Ford in the unforgiving conditions.

🗺️ Route Details

Centered in the Troodos Mountains, Cyprus featured narrow gravel tracks with minimal runoff and frequent elevation changes. Key stages included:

  • Lagoudera: Tight switchbacks and climbing sections that tested torque and traction control under heat stress.
  • Foini: Rough and rutted — heavily degraded after first passes, with sharp rocks and dust traps everywhere.
  • Koilani: A mix of wider sections and technical corners — favored drivers who could adapt to changing grip levels.

The combination of high temperatures, sharp rocks, and long liaison sections made it a true test of survival as much as speed.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Carlos Sainz & Luis Moya (Ford Focus WRC)

2nd Place: Colin McRae & Nicky Grist (Ford Focus WRC)

3rd Place: Richard Burns & Robert Reid (Subaru Impreza S6 WRC)

Sainz drove intelligently, preserving his car and tires while others pushed too hard and paid the price. McRae backed off late in the rally to secure a Ford 1–2, while Burns completed the podium after consistent pace and careful tire management.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Ford Focus WRC: Tough and balanced — survived brutal terrain thanks to robust suspension and improved cooling systems.
  • Subaru Impreza S6 WRC: Strong and reliable — Burns used it effectively in hot, slow-speed sections, but it struggled to match Ford’s corner stability.
  • Peugeot 206 WRC: Fast but fragile — suffered under the intense physical stress of Cypriot roads, limiting its challenge for victory.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Low Average Speeds: With many stages under 70 km/h average, concentration and note timing were more important than outright pace.
  • Rough Terrain: Suspension and tire damage were common — smart lines and mechanical sympathy separated contenders from casualties.
  • Heat Management: Cockpit and engine temps soared — driver hydration and cooling strategies were crucial.

Carlos Sainz’s triumph in Cyprus was a masterclass in strategic rallying — less about raw speed, more about patience, control, and experience when the conditions turned brutal.

events.title: 2000 Tour de Corse – Rallye de France (France)
events.bio: Gilles Panizzi reaffirmed his status as Peugeot’s tarmac specialist by storming to victory on the twisting mountain roads of Corsica, executing a near-flawless drive with co-driver and brother Hervé in the Peugeot 206 WRC.
events.details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 2000 Tour de Corse – Rallye de France (France)

Date: September 28 – October 1, 2000

Start Location: Ajaccio, Corsica

Finish Location: Ajaccio, Corsica

Total Distance: ~1,100 km (estimated full route)

Competitive Stages: 385.01 km

Surface: Asphalt

The 2000 Tour de Corse was a classic test of technical asphalt rallying. With its endless hairpins and fast descents, the Corsican roads demanded precision, rhythm, and nerve. Gilles Panizzi delivered all three, controlling the rally from start to finish in a dominant Peugeot 206 WRC display, while brother Hervé provided perfect co-driver timing across the island's unforgiving tarmac.

🗺️ Route Details

Known as the “Rally of 10,000 Corners,” Corsica’s stages are narrow, twisting, and constantly changing. Key stages included:

  • Vico–Sarrola: Steep gradients and sharp bends — heavy on brakes and traction, especially under dry conditions.
  • Murzo–Ambiegna: A rhythm stage with flowing medium-speed curves and elevation shifts.
  • Pont de Casaglione: Fast descents into tight village sections — required surgical braking precision.

Dry and sunny conditions throughout gave drivers a stable surface to push to the limit — tire strategy centered on heat management and grip consistency over longer loops.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Gilles Panizzi & Hervé Panizzi (Peugeot 206 WRC)

2nd Place: Richard Burns & Robert Reid (Subaru Impreza S6 WRC)

3rd Place: François Delecour & Daniel Grataloup (Peugeot 206 WRC)

Panizzi dominated from the outset, building a gap on day one that he managed expertly. Burns showed his growing tarmac capability, while Delecour made it two Peugeots on the podium with a tidy drive of his own.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Peugeot 206 WRC: Small, agile, and perfectly suited to Corsican roads — unmatched in tight transitions and braking stability.
  • Subaru Impreza S6 WRC: Powerful and more balanced than previous years — Burns made the most of its increased tarmac competitiveness.
  • Ford Focus WRC: Strong package but unable to match Peugeot’s nimbleness — struggled in ultra-tight cornering zones.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Corner Density: With hundreds of corners per stage, co-driver timing and driver rhythm were essential — one late call could send a car into the cliffs.
  • Tire Management: Asphalt temperatures rose by mid-day — conserving compound grip across long loops became a key factor.
  • Local Mastery: Panizzi’s Corsican familiarity and comfort with relentless cornering made him virtually untouchable all weekend.

Gilles Panizzi’s Tour de Corse win was a masterclass in asphalt rallying — combining raw pace, control, and local knowledge to deliver one of the most dominant tarmac performances of the 2000 season.

events.title: 2000 Rallye Sanremo – Rallye d’Italia (Italy)
events.bio: Gilles Panizzi continued his tarmac dominance by taking a stylish win at the 2000 Rallye Sanremo, dancing his Peugeot 206 WRC through the Ligurian hills with clinical precision and flair.
events.details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 2000 Rallye Sanremo – Rallye d’Italia (Italy)

Date: October 19–22, 2000

Start Location: Sanremo, Italy

Finish Location: Sanremo, Italy

Total Distance: ~1,100 km (estimated full route)

Competitive Stages: 382.79 km

Surface: Asphalt

The 2000 Sanremo Rally played perfectly into Gilles Panizzi’s hands — a tarmac specialist on tight, twisty Ligurian roads. Building off his Corsica momentum, he used the agile Peugeot 206 WRC to full effect, weaving through technical mountain stages and narrow village lanes to take a confident back-to-back asphalt victory for Peugeot.

🗺️ Route Details

Sanremo’s unique layout combined high-altitude switchbacks, village sprints, and quick tarmac transitions. Key stages included:

  • Colle d’Oggia: Classic uphill stage with hairpin after hairpin — favored torque and late braking.
  • Bajardo: A complex stage blending open-flowing corners with tight cliff-side sections.
  • Perinaldo: Narrow and technical — required immaculate precision through chicanes and blind crests.

Conditions remained dry and clean across the event, giving Panizzi the confidence to push hard from stage one and control the rally throughout.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Gilles Panizzi & Hervé Panizzi (Peugeot 206 WRC)

2nd Place: Richard Burns & Robert Reid (Subaru Impreza S6 WRC)

3rd Place: François Delecour & Daniel Grataloup (Peugeot 206 WRC)

Panizzi controlled the pace with finesse, while Burns again demonstrated growing tarmac skill. Delecour made it two Peugeots on the podium, helping close the manufacturers’ points gap.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Peugeot 206 WRC: Quick rotation, light frame, and great cornering balance — ideal for Italy’s switchbacks and high-grip tarmac.
  • Subaru Impreza S6 WRC: Improved asphalt behavior over previous years — powerful and stable, especially in medium-speed corners.
  • Ford Focus WRC: Capable and consistent, but lacked the nimbleness of the Peugeot in tighter sections.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Technical Precision: Sanremo’s narrow roads required millimeter-perfect lines — especially on mountain passes with no guardrails.
  • Pacenote Timing: Constant corner transitions and short acceleration bursts meant co-drivers had to be flawlessly in sync.
  • Momentum Over Power: The key to success in Sanremo was rhythm — something Panizzi delivered flawlessly from the first stage.

The Panizzi brothers' win in Sanremo marked a golden stretch for Peugeot’s tarmac campaign and further established Gilles as the undisputed asphalt ace of the early 2000s.

events.title: 2000 Rally of Malaysia (Malaysia)
events.bio: Possum Bourne once again demonstrated his dominance in the Asia-Pacific Rally Championship with a commanding win in Malaysia, navigating treacherous tropical gravel stages in the Subaru Impreza WRX with co-driver Mark Stacey.
events.details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 2000 Rally of Malaysia (Malaysia)

Date: October 6–8, 2000

Start Location: Johor Bahru, Malaysia

Finish Location: Johor Bahru, Malaysia

Total Distance: ~900 km (estimated full route)

Competitive Stages: ~240 km

Surface: Gravel

Part of the FIA Asia-Pacific Rally Championship (APRC), the 2000 Rally of Malaysia brought extreme heat, humidity, and slippery jungle gravel to the forefront. Possum Bourne capitalized on his experience and composure under pressure to dominate the tropical terrain and claim another regional victory in the Subaru Impreza WRX.

🗺️ Route Details

The rally utilized palm oil plantation roads and forest trails, offering fast, narrow gravel tracks lined with thick vegetation. Key route features included:

  • Low Grip Conditions: Slick clay-based gravel made even more treacherous by rainfall and humidity.
  • Jungle Sections: Claustrophobic tree-lined roads demanded maximum precision and limited visibility.
  • Drainage Cuts: Fast roads with deep ruts and water damage — hard on suspensions and driver focus.

The tropical climate made car setup and tire selection a constant battle between cooling efficiency and traction control under unpredictable weather swings.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Possum Bourne & Mark Stacey (Subaru Impreza WRX)

2nd Place: Karamjit Singh & Allen Oh (Proton Pert)

3rd Place: Armin Kremer & Klaus Wicha (Mitsubishi Lancer Evo VI)

Bourne led from the front, showing measured aggression in slippery conditions. Singh delighted the home crowd with a strong second-place finish, while Kremer battled heat and visibility issues to complete the podium.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Subaru Impreza WRX: Reliable and consistent — strong torque delivery and traction suited the slick Malaysian gravel perfectly.
  • Proton Pert: Lightweight and nimble — Singh’s car had the pace but lacked the Subaru’s damping through deeper ruts.
  • Mitsubishi Lancer Evo VI: Durable but heavier — struggled slightly in tighter jungle sections but excelled in the open stages.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Jungle Heat: Cockpit temperatures exceeded 45°C — driver endurance and hydration were mission-critical.
  • Grip Variation: Sun-baked clay gave way to slick mud without warning — precise throttle and steering input were vital.
  • Wildlife & Vegetation: Sudden appearances of animals and dense foliage forced quick reactions and exact line selection.

Possum Bourne’s Malaysian win underlined his mastery of endurance rallying — combining intelligence, stamina, and skill to dominate in one of the toughest climates on the APRC calendar.

events.title: 2000 Rally of Thailand (Thailand)
events.bio: Karamjit Singh and co-driver Allen Oh captured a milestone victory at the 2000 Rally of Thailand, mastering the dusty, rutted roads in their Proton Pert to secure a crucial win in the Asia-Pacific Rally Championship.
events.details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 2000 Rally of Thailand (Thailand)

Date: October 27–29, 2000

Start Location: Bangkok, Thailand

Finish Location: Bangkok, Thailand

Total Distance: ~800 km (estimated full route)

Competitive Stages: ~244 km

Surface: Gravel

The 2000 Rally of Thailand offered up a mix of dry, dusty trails and high humidity, posing a technical challenge for drivers in the final leg of the Asia-Pacific Rally Championship season. Malaysian rally star Karamjit Singh, in top form, steered his Proton Pert to victory with co-driver Allen Oh, taking a major step forward in establishing Proton as a serious contender in international rallying.

🗺️ Route Details

Thailand’s stages ran through plantation roads, loose gravel forestry trails, and red clay tracks. Common route characteristics included:

  • Dry, Loose Surfaces: Reduced grip and deep dust clouds challenged braking zones and visibility.
  • Fast Mid-Speed Corners: Long sweeping bends with varying camber — crucial to maintain momentum through the dust.
  • Ruts and Washouts: Previous rainfall had created sections with significant erosion and rock exposure.

The humid tropical environment added an extra layer of fatigue to both drivers and cars, demanding careful setup and stamina management.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Karamjit Singh & Allen Oh (Proton Pert)

2nd Place: Possum Bourne & Mark Stacey (Subaru Impreza WRX)

3rd Place: Armin Kremer & Klaus Wicha (Mitsubishi Lancer Evo VI)

Singh took command early and maintained control throughout, while Bourne kept the pressure on in the later stages. Kremer rounded out the podium with a solid, measured drive in increasingly dusty conditions.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Proton Pert: Light and agile with Mitsubishi-derived drivetrain — Singh exploited its balance and torque to full effect.
  • Subaru Impreza WRX: Durable and composed — Bourne’s experience helped him manage the tough terrain, though he couldn’t match Singh’s pace.
  • Mitsubishi Lancer Evo VI: Reliable and quick, especially in straight-line sections — but required more finesse through tight transitions.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Visibility: Hanging dust from earlier cars made note timing critical — Singh benefited from clean air with his early lead.
  • Heat & Humidity: In-cabin temps pushed over 45°C — drivers and co-drivers needed careful hydration and pacing.
  • Changing Terrain: Dry dust turned to compact clay in shaded zones, creating uneven grip and surprise traction loss.

The Thailand win was a proud moment for Karamjit Singh and Proton, capping off a season of steady progression with a breakthrough victory in one of Asia’s toughest gravel events.

events.title: 2000 Telstra Rally Australia (Australia)
events.bio: Marcus Grönholm sealed his first World Rally Championship title with a dominant performance in Perth, mastering the ultra-fast forest roads of Rally Australia in his Peugeot 206 WRC.
events.details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 2000 Telstra Rally Australia (Australia)

Date: November 9–12, 2000

Start Location: Perth, Western Australia

Finish Location: Perth, Western Australia

Total Distance: ~1,300 km (estimated full route)

Competitive Stages: 391.17 km

Surface: Gravel

The 2000 Rally Australia was a career-defining moment for Marcus Grönholm. Blending blistering pace with calm control on Western Australia’s high-speed gravel, he stormed to victory and clinched the World Championship title with one round to spare. His Peugeot 206 WRC was faultless, while his rivals struggled to match the Finn’s rhythm and commitment through the trees.

🗺️ Route Details

The rally featured lightning-fast gravel tracks through eucalyptus forests near Perth. Key stages included:

  • Ballingup: Smooth gravel with sweeping turns and crest-jumps — required absolute precision.
  • Wellington Dam: Dense tree-lined roads with narrow lines and minimal room for error.
  • Mundaring Super Special: A fan-favorite nighttime stage run head-to-head on parallel tracks in front of packed grandstands.

Dry conditions meant consistent grip but added the challenge of dust trails and low visibility for following cars.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Marcus Grönholm & Timo Rautiainen (Peugeot 206 WRC)

2nd Place: Richard Burns & Robert Reid (Subaru Impreza S6 WRC)

3rd Place: Carlos Sainz & Luis Moya (Ford Focus WRC)

Grönholm led from the outset and held off a strong challenge from Burns, who kept the pressure on in a last-ditch title bid. Sainz drove consistently to claim the final podium spot and help Ford in the constructors' race.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Peugeot 206 WRC: Perfectly suited to Australia’s fast, technical gravel — excellent turn-in and suspension tuning gave Grönholm a razor-sharp edge.
  • Subaru Impreza S6 WRC: Stable and powerful — Burns kept the fight alive with consistent stage times but lacked just enough pace to catch the leader.
  • Ford Focus WRC: Solid platform — good through tight sequences, but fell behind in the long high-speed sections.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Tight Margins: Fast stages left no room for error — millisecond-level decisions at 180 km/h between trees defined the top runs.
  • Dust & Light Conditions: Afternoon sun and airborne gravel created glare and haze — early road position was crucial.
  • Championship Pressure: Grönholm kept his nerve in the face of the biggest moment of his career, driving with calm dominance.

With his win in Australia, Marcus Grönholm captured the 2000 WRC Drivers’ Championship in stunning fashion — a fitting finale to a season of rising confidence, raw speed, and cool-headed execution.

events.title: 2000 Network Q Rally of Great Britain (United Kingdom)
events.bio: Richard Burns closed the 2000 WRC season with a resounding win on home soil, mastering the slick Welsh forests in his Subaru Impreza S6 WRC and securing his third consecutive RAC Rally victory.
events.details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 2000 Network Q Rally of Great Britain (United Kingdom)

Date: November 23–26, 2000

Start Location: Cardiff, Wales

Finish Location: Cardiff, Wales

Total Distance: ~1,600 km (estimated full route)

Competitive Stages: 380.80 km

Surface: Gravel/Mud

The final round of the 2000 WRC season saw the British forests soaked with rain, turning the gravel stages into slick, muddy gauntlets. Richard Burns, already runner-up in the championship, delivered a masterful wet-weather performance to win the RAC Rally for the third year running — much to the delight of the home crowd in Wales.

🗺️ Route Details

The rally covered iconic forest stages in Wales, many of which are among the most historic and demanding in the WRC. Key stages included:

  • Myherin: Long, flowing gravel with fast sections and deep standing water — very tricky in wet weather.
  • Sweet Lamb: A mix of open hillside and tight forest sections — packed with fans and high-speed water splashes.
  • Dyfi: Slippery forest roads lined with deep ditches — a classic test of patience and traction control.

Rainfall made conditions treacherous, with reduced grip and heavy mud build-up on tire treads and wheel wells.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Richard Burns & Robert Reid (Subaru Impreza S6 WRC)

2nd Place: Colin McRae & Nicky Grist (Ford Focus WRC)

3rd Place: Marcus Grönholm & Timo Rautiainen (Peugeot 206 WRC)

Burns surged into the lead early and managed his pace perfectly across the remaining stages. McRae thrilled fans with his typically fearless attack through the mud, while newly-crowned World Champion Grönholm drove cautiously to secure valuable manufacturer points for Peugeot.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Subaru Impreza S6 WRC: Exceptional grip and damping — ideal for the muddy and wet British forest roads.
  • Ford Focus WRC: Responsive and balanced — McRae extracted maximum performance in treacherous conditions.
  • Peugeot 206 WRC: Quick on drier stages, but slightly less composed in deep mud compared to Subaru and Ford.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Low Visibility: Fog and rain blanketed the stages — driver concentration and accurate pacenotes were essential.
  • Mud Management: Constant traction changes made throttle control and line choice a moving target — precision outweighed speed.
  • Home Pressure: Burns and McRae both had fan expectations riding on them — Burns delivered in style with another wet-weather masterclass.

Burns’ third consecutive RAC Rally win capped off a stellar season and confirmed his reputation as one of the sport’s wet-weather specialists — a defiant final flourish in a thrilling WRC title campaign.

events.title: 2001 Rallye Monte-Carlo (Monaco)
events.bio: Tommi Mäkinen took an early lead in the 2001 WRC season with a composed and strategic drive through Monte Carlo’s notoriously unpredictable conditions, earning his third consecutive Monte win in the Mitsubishi Lancer Evo VI.
events.details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 2001 Rallye Monte-Carlo (Monaco)

Date: January 19–21, 2001

Start Location: Monaco

Finish Location: Monaco

Total Distance: ~1,300 km (estimated full route)

Competitive Stages: ~388 km

Surface: Asphalt/Snow

The 2001 Rallye Monte-Carlo kicked off the new WRC season with its signature blend of narrow mountain tarmac, patchy snow, and strategic tire gambles. Tommi Mäkinen once again proved masterful in mixed conditions, using careful tire calls and calm execution to take victory in the final year of the Mitsubishi Lancer Evo VI’s WRC frontline use.

🗺️ Route Details

Based in the French Alps above the principality, the Monte Carlo stages are notorious for sudden changes in elevation, temperature, and traction. Key stages included:

  • Col de Turini: The rally’s most iconic test — long night stages with icy hairpins and narrow cliffside roads packed with fans.
  • Sisteron: A strategic tire challenge — featured both dry tarmac and deep ice within the same stage.
  • Lucéram–Lantosque: Fast descents and variable grip made it a make-or-break test of commitment and adaptability.

Changing surface grip required near-perfect pacenote trust and real-time adaptation by both driver and co-driver throughout the event.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Tommi Mäkinen & Risto Mannisenmäki (Mitsubishi Lancer Evo VI)

2nd Place: Carlos Sainz & Luis Moya (Ford Focus WRC)

3rd Place: François Delecour & Daniel Grataloup (Peugeot 206 WRC)

Mäkinen’s consistency kept him clear of trouble, while Sainz pushed hard in the final leg but couldn’t close the gap. Delecour delivered a surprise podium for Peugeot with a clean, confident drive.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Mitsubishi Lancer Evo VI: In its final works season — proved it could still win with proper setup and reliability in unpredictable terrain.
  • Ford Focus WRC: Stable and strong under braking — well-balanced on both slick asphalt and light snow.
  • Peugeot 206 WRC: Agile but challenged by the changing grip — Delecour extracted the maximum from it on drier loops.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Surface Variability: Drivers had to handle wet tarmac, dry asphalt, slush, and black ice — often within one stage.
  • Tire Choices: The wrong compound could destroy a rally — Mäkinen’s conservative picks paid off repeatedly.
  • Col de Turini Pressure: The night run through Turini created intense media and fan attention — magnifying every braking and throttle choice.

Tommi Mäkinen’s third consecutive Monte Carlo victory showed his cool under pressure and supreme mastery of low-grip driving — a testament to both experience and precise execution.

events.title: 2001 Dakar Rally (Paris–Dakar, France to Senegal)
events.bio: Jutta Kleinschmidt made history by becoming the first woman to win the Dakar Rally, piloting her Mitsubishi Pajero to victory over nearly 11,000 km of brutal terrain from Paris to Dakar alongside co-driver Andreas Schulz.
events.details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 2001 Dakar Rally (Paris–Dakar)

Date: January 1–21, 2001

Start Location: Paris, France

Finish Location: Dakar, Senegal

Total Distance: ~10,700 km

Competitive Stages: ~6,700 km

Surface: Mixed Terrain (Desert, Sand, Gravel, Rocks, Savannah)

The 2001 edition of the Dakar Rally followed the classic westbound route from Paris to Dakar, crossing through France, Spain, Morocco, Mauritania, Mali, and Senegal. Jutta Kleinschmidt delivered a landmark performance, combining speed, strategic navigation, and endurance to claim overall victory — the first time a woman won the legendary event in its history.

🗺️ Route Details

The rally featured a brutal 21-day itinerary with nearly 11,000 km of terrain. Major segments included:

  • Moroccan Atlas: Rocky mountain passes and early navigation traps defined the first major off-road tests.
  • Western Sahara & Mauritania: Endless dunes, deep camel grass, and shifting sands pushed drivers to the brink of endurance.
  • Mali to Senegal: Fast savannah tracks with dense foliage and dry river crossings — final legs demanded caution and concentration.

Minimal outside support and brutal conditions throughout ensured that only the best-prepared crews would reach the finish line in Dakar.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Jutta Kleinschmidt & Andreas Schulz (Mitsubishi Pajero)

2nd Place: Hiroshi Masuoka & Pascal Maimon (Mitsubishi Pajero)

3rd Place: Jean-Louis Schlesser & Henri Magne (Schlesser-Renault Buggy)

Kleinschmidt’s steady approach and clean navigation gave her the edge over teammates and rivals. Masuoka showed speed but couldn’t recover lost time, while Schlesser’s buggy excelled in the dunes but struggled in rocky sections.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Mitsubishi Pajero: Proven rally raid machine — durable, balanced, and well-suited for the Dakar’s mix of dunes and high-speed tracks.
  • Schlesser-Renault Buggy: Fast and agile on sand but prone to mechanical wear in rockier terrain — Schlesser’s aggressive style wasn’t enough to close the gap.
  • Nissan & Toyota Privateers: Several privateer teams impressed with reliability and survival instincts but lacked the pace of the factory entries.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Navigation Complexity: GPS limitations meant co-drivers had to rely on road books and landmarks — Schulz’s accuracy was vital to Kleinschmidt’s success.
  • Mechanical Attrition: Rough dunes and rock fields caused hundreds of retirements — Mitsubishi’s preparation paid off with multiple cars finishing in the top five.
  • Historic Milestone: Kleinschmidt’s victory broke barriers in motorsport and was widely celebrated as a breakthrough moment for female competitors globally.

The 2001 Paris–Dakar Rally was a test of endurance, navigation, and resilience — and Jutta Kleinschmidt’s triumph stands as one of the event’s most iconic and groundbreaking moments.

events.title: 2001 Swedish Rally (Sweden)
events.bio: Harri Rovanperä captured his first and only WRC victory in the snow-laden forests of Sweden, delivering a dominant performance in the Peugeot 206 WRC alongside co-driver Risto Pietiläinen.
events.details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 2001 Swedish Rally (Sweden)

Date: February 9–11, 2001

Start Location: Karlstad, Sweden

Finish Location: Karlstad, Sweden

Total Distance: ~1,500 km (estimated full route)

Competitive Stages: ~380 km

Surface: Snow

The 2001 Swedish Rally presented ideal winter rallying conditions — deep snowbanks, frozen roads, and subzero temperatures. Harri Rovanperä took full advantage, showcasing fearless speed and composure to dominate the event and score his maiden WRC win in the Peugeot 206 WRC. It was a proud moment for both the Finnish driver and the French manufacturer.

🗺️ Route Details

Held in the forests of Värmland, the Swedish stages are among the fastest in WRC when run in deep snow. Key stages included:

  • Hagfors: Smooth, packed-snow surface with long sweeping corners — rewarded bravery and throttle balance.
  • Torsby: Narrow and lined with snowbanks — used tactically by drivers for extra cornering support.
  • Fredriksberg: Featured long straights and tight transitions — studded tires were essential for maximizing grip.

Temperatures stayed consistently cold, preserving the snowbanks and delivering optimal rally conditions throughout the weekend.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Harri Rovanperä & Risto Pietiläinen (Peugeot 206 WRC)

2nd Place: Marcus Grönholm & Timo Rautiainen (Peugeot 206 WRC)

3rd Place: Tommi Mäkinen & Risto Mannisenmäki (Mitsubishi Lancer Evo VI)

Rovanperä set the tone from day one and kept the lead throughout, with teammate Grönholm backing off to secure a safe 1–2 for Peugeot. Mäkinen pushed hard but couldn’t match the French cars’ pace in the snow.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Peugeot 206 WRC: Light, responsive, and with excellent traction — it thrived in snowy conditions and fast, flowing corners.
  • Mitsubishi Lancer Evo VI: Durable and powerful — still competitive in snow but beginning to show its age against newer chassis.
  • Subaru Impreza S7 WRC: Stable and predictable — lacked a bit of bite in tighter snow corners but remained a fan favorite.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Snowbank Strategy: Drivers leaned into the banks for support — but too much risked getting stuck or rolling.
  • Studded Tires: Precision braking and acceleration depended on maintaining sharp tire studs throughout the rally.
  • Driver Rhythm: Fast average speeds demanded perfect pacenote syncing — especially in long sequences of blind crests and sweeping turns.

Harri Rovanperä’s win in Sweden marked a highlight of his career and cemented his place in WRC history as one of the snow masters of the early 2000s.

events.title: 2001 Safari Rally Kenya (Kenya)
events.bio: Colin McRae conquered the grueling Kenyan terrain to win the final World Championship edition of the legendary Safari Rally, guiding his Ford Focus WRC through rocks, wildlife, and searing heat for one of the most demanding victories of his career.
events.details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 2001 Safari Rally Kenya (Kenya)

Date: February 23–25, 2001

Start Location: Nairobi, Kenya

Finish Location: Nairobi, Kenya

Total Distance: ~2,000 km (estimated full route)

Competitive Stages: ~960 km

Surface: Gravel

The 2001 Safari Rally marked the end of an era, as the final time Kenya’s iconic event would appear on the WRC calendar until its return two decades later. Colin McRae delivered a heroic performance in the harshest conditions imaginable — battling deep ruts, wildlife, dust, and relentless mechanical strain to claim a commanding win for Ford in one of the toughest rallies in the world.

🗺️ Route Details

Held across the wild landscapes around Nairobi, the Safari featured open-road competitive sections, long liaisons, and extreme endurance demands. Notable segments included:

  • Ngong Hills: Open plains with high-speed potential but hidden dangers — animals, washouts, and loose rock fields.
  • Amboseli Zone: Hot, dry, and heavily rutted — challenged cooling systems and suspension setups.
  • Elementaita: Fast sections with deep water crossings and unpredictable dust plumes.

The average speed was significantly higher than typical rallies, but so were the consequences of mechanical failure or missed navigation.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Colin McRae & Nicky Grist (Ford Focus WRC)

2nd Place: Harri Rovanperä & Risto Pietiläinen (Peugeot 206 WRC)

3rd Place: Didier Auriol & Denis Giraudet (Peugeot 206 WRC)

McRae took the lead early and maintained it through a combination of speed and careful preservation. Peugeot’s drivers pushed hard but lost time to mechanical issues and navigation troubles in the treacherous terrain.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Ford Focus WRC: Ruggedized for Safari use — reinforced suspension and added cooling ducts proved essential to survival and success.
  • Peugeot 206 WRC: Light and fast, but less tolerant to the Safari’s abuse — both Rovanperä and Auriol showed pace but faced repairs.
  • Mitsubishi Lancer Evo VI: Struggled with mechanical issues and failed to match the pace or resilience of its rivals.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Open Road Format: No pace notes — drivers relied on road books and co-driver guidance in real time over vast distances.
  • Wildlife & Hazards: Animals, local traffic, and terrain damage all contributed to the Safari’s unmatched unpredictability.
  • Mechanical Endurance: Punctures, overheating, and suspension failure were constant threats — only the most durable cars made it to the end.

McRae’s victory in Kenya was not just another win — it was a farewell to one of the sport’s most iconic events, and a reminder that endurance, patience, and raw skill are sometimes the only ways to conquer the wildest rally on Earth.

events.title: 2001 Rallye de Portugal (Portugal)
events.bio: Colin McRae braved treacherous weather and unforgiving gravel to secure his second consecutive win of the season at Rallye de Portugal, pushing his Ford Focus WRC to the limit through rain-soaked stages.
events.details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 2001 Rallye de Portugal (Portugal)

Date: March 8–11, 2001

Start Location: Matosinhos, Portugal

Finish Location: Matosinhos, Portugal

Total Distance: ~1,200 km (estimated full route)

Competitive Stages: ~385 km

Surface: Gravel (wet and muddy conditions)

The 2001 Rallye de Portugal lived up to its reputation for drama and chaos, as torrential rains turned many of the stages into slick, rutted traps. Colin McRae stayed composed amid the carnage, navigating the changing grip and heavy fog to clinch back-to-back victories and keep Ford’s title hopes alive early in the season.

🗺️ Route Details

Set in the hills of northern Portugal, the route included deep ruts, standing water, and treacherous corners. Notable stages included:

  • Arganil: Portugal’s most famous stage — rough, narrow, and foggy with steep drop-offs and muddy surfaces.
  • Fafe: Legendary for its massive jump and frenzied fans — demanded full commitment on soaked gravel.
  • Mortágua: A technical mix of fast corners and tight chicanes with deep water-cut ruts.

The weather wreaked havoc, with several stages canceled due to impassability and dozens of retirements caused by crashes and mechanical damage.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Colin McRae & Nicky Grist (Ford Focus WRC)

2nd Place: Carlos Sainz & Luis Moya (Ford Focus WRC)

3rd Place: Harri Rovanperä & Risto Pietiläinen (Peugeot 206 WRC)

McRae built his lead through consistent speed and survival, while Sainz secured a clean 1–2 finish for Ford by avoiding major risks. Rovanperä recovered from early delays to take a solid podium in the battered Peugeot.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Ford Focus WRC: Exceptional traction and water resilience — excelled in the extreme mud and slippery ruts.
  • Peugeot 206 WRC: Agile and fast in drier sections, but struggled with ride height and suspension in deeper mud.
  • Mitsubishi Lancer Evo VI: Solid but outdated — dropped pace in comparison to Ford and Peugeot’s latest evolutions.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Weather Impact: Heavy rain and low visibility led to unpredictable grip and timing chaos — crews had to adapt in real time.
  • Surface Erosion: Repeated passes tore up the gravel base — deep ruts and water channels forced frequent tire and line adjustments.
  • Driver Discipline: Patience was key — McRae balanced aggression and control, pushing when conditions allowed and surviving when they didn’t.

Colin McRae’s win in Portugal further solidified his 2001 title ambitions, proving that raw speed combined with tactical restraint could overcome even the worst weather rallying had to offer.

events.title: 2001 Rally Catalunya – Costa Brava (Spain)
events.bio: Didier Auriol returned to the top step of the WRC podium with a precise and confident drive on Spain’s flowing asphalt roads, mastering the Rally Catalunya in his Peugeot 206 WRC.
events.details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 2001 Rally Catalunya – Costa Brava (Spain)

Date: March 23–25, 2001

Start Location: Lloret de Mar, Spain

Finish Location: Lloret de Mar, Spain

Total Distance: ~1,200 km (estimated full route)

Competitive Stages: ~395 km

Surface: Asphalt

The 2001 Rally Catalunya brought pristine asphalt and springtime sun to the WRC calendar. Didier Auriol, the 1994 World Champion, used his vast experience and smooth tarmac style to full effect, delivering a commanding win for Peugeot on the fast, sweeping Spanish mountain roads. It marked his final WRC career victory — a masterclass of precision and patience.

🗺️ Route Details

Based in the Catalonian hills, the stages were wide, fast, and circuit-like in character — demanding clean lines and full commitment. Notable stages included:

  • Els Àngels: Long, flowing corners and elevation changes made it a rhythm-critical challenge.
  • La Trona: Technical downhill braking zones combined with sweeping high-speed entries.
  • Santa Pellaia: A mix of fast straights and tight twisty portions — excellent for testing car balance and grip.

Dry and consistent weather throughout allowed crews to focus purely on speed, tire strategy, and pace execution without weather disruptions.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Didier Auriol & Denis Giraudet (Peugeot 206 WRC)

2nd Place: Richard Burns & Robert Reid (Subaru Impreza S7 WRC)

3rd Place: Carlos Sainz & Luis Moya (Ford Focus WRC)

Auriol set the pace early and maintained it with controlled aggression. Burns pushed hard late in the event but couldn’t overcome the time deficit, while Sainz gave Spanish fans a podium to cheer for on home ground.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Peugeot 206 WRC: Light, agile, and perfectly tuned for asphalt — its short wheelbase allowed superb rotation through tight sections.
  • Subaru Impreza S7 WRC: Stable and fast — Burns used its grip advantage well, particularly in long sweepers.
  • Ford Focus WRC: Well-balanced but struggled slightly in rapid directional changes compared to the Peugeot.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Line Discipline: Maintaining racing lines at high speed was critical — errors in corner exit could ruin an entire split.
  • Brake Management: Long downhill sectors required careful modulation to avoid fade and time loss late in stages.
  • Pace Note Precision: With few visual markers and very fast sections, co-driver timing had to be flawless.

Didier Auriol’s win in Catalunya was a vintage display of technical tarmac driving, and a fitting final triumph for one of rallying’s most elegant and respected champions.

events.title: 2001 Rally Argentina (Argentina)
events.bio: Tommi Mäkinen powered through the fast and rugged gravel of the Cordoba highlands to claim victory at Rally Argentina, demonstrating the continued competitiveness of the Mitsubishi Lancer Evo VI in tough South American conditions.
events.details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 2001 Rally Argentina (Argentina)

Date: May 3–6, 2001

Start Location: Villa Carlos Paz, Argentina

Finish Location: Villa Carlos Paz, Argentina

Total Distance: ~1,300 km (estimated full route)

Competitive Stages: ~382 km

Surface: Gravel

The 2001 Rally Argentina offered up classic South American rallying: high-speed gravel tracks, water splashes, and changing weather conditions. Tommi Mäkinen rose to the challenge, combining experience and aggression to fend off strong opposition and take a well-earned win — his third career victory in Argentina and a vital boost for Mitsubishi’s campaign.

🗺️ Route Details

Set in the Sierras de Córdoba, the stages delivered a mix of fast open terrain and tight, technical forested sections. Key stages included:

  • El Condor – Copina: Narrow, rocky climbs with thick fog and thousands of fans — a true WRC classic.
  • Mina Clavero: Fast and flowing with heavy compression zones and water fords — very hard on suspension.
  • Santa Rosa: Long straights with loose gravel and unexpected surface transitions — required focus and brake management.

The weather fluctuated across the weekend, adding an extra layer of unpredictability as damp patches caught out several top crews.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Tommi Mäkinen & Risto Mannisenmäki (Mitsubishi Lancer Evo VI)

2nd Place: Carlos Sainz & Luis Moya (Ford Focus WRC)

3rd Place: Richard Burns & Robert Reid (Subaru Impreza S7 WRC)

Mäkinen controlled the pace throughout, managing tires and mechanical wear expertly. Sainz showed solid consistency to bring home second, while Burns recovered from early handling issues to claim third on a demanding weekend.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Mitsubishi Lancer Evo VI: Proven durability and torque delivery — thrived on rough, high-altitude stages with strong grip and resilience.
  • Ford Focus WRC: Agile and stable — great through mid-speed corners and excellent on long braking zones.
  • Subaru Impreza S7 WRC: Well-balanced but struggled early with oversteer — improved setup later delivered solid pace and podium position.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Water Crossings: Numerous river fords required speed control and careful throttle use to avoid engine stall or splash damage.
  • Surface Shifts: Sections transitioned from hard-packed gravel to loose stone — grip varied rapidly between corners.
  • Altitude Effects: Thinner air affected engine power and driver concentration — strategic pacing was crucial.

Mäkinen’s win in Argentina reaffirmed his status as one of gravel’s greats and reminded the WRC field that the veteran Finn and Mitsubishi still had the speed to fight for top honors in 2001.

events.title: 2001 Rally of Canberra (Australia)
events.bio: Karamjit Singh took a crucial win at the 2001 Rally of Canberra, showcasing his consistency and pace in the Proton Pert as he marched toward the APRC championship title.
events.details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 2001 Rally of Canberra (Australia)

Date: May 4–6, 2001

Start Location: Canberra, ACT, Australia

Finish Location: Canberra, ACT, Australia

Total Distance: ~800 km (estimated full route)

Competitive Stages: ~230 km

Surface: Gravel

Part of the Asia-Pacific Rally Championship (APRC), the 2001 Rally of Canberra featured fast but technical gravel roads through eucalyptus forests and hilly terrain. Karamjit Singh and co-driver Allen Oh delivered a clean and composed drive to take top honors — a key result on their way to securing the 2001 APRC title.

🗺️ Route Details

The rally included flowing forestry tracks and narrow hillside roads around Tidbinbilla and Cotter Dam. Notable challenges included:

  • Dust and Pine Needles: Low visibility and loose surfaces made braking zones unpredictable.
  • Elevation Changes: Sharp climbs and descents required strong torque and careful braking balance.
  • Tight Technical Sections: Demanded exact throttle control and precise line choice to avoid clipping banks and stumps.

Cool autumn weather kept engine temperatures stable, but the dry gravel and dusty air tested both driver focus and filtration systems.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Karamjit Singh & Allen Oh (Proton Pert)

2nd Place: Possum Bourne & Mark Stacey (Subaru Impreza WRX)

3rd Place: Kenneth Eriksson & Staffan Parmander (Hyundai Accent WRC)

Singh’s steady approach and local familiarity helped him edge out rally icon Possum Bourne, while Eriksson fought mechanical issues but still secured a podium for Hyundai’s APRC campaign.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Proton Pert: Lightweight, well-balanced, and reliable — Singh used its nimbleness to perfection on narrow forest roads.
  • Subaru Impreza WRX: Powerhouse on straights — quick in open stages but slightly heavier through tight transitions.
  • Hyundai Accent WRC: Competitive but suffered minor gremlins — Eriksson’s experience helped it stay in contention.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Blind Crests: Many stage sections featured dips and sudden crests — co-driver accuracy was crucial.
  • Loose Surface Grip: Dry gravel reduced traction mid-stage — Singh excelled at modulating grip and throttle balance.
  • Championship Stakes: As an early APRC round, the result played a major role in shaping the overall season — Singh capitalized perfectly.

The Rally of Canberra win was a cornerstone in Karamjit Singh’s successful APRC championship campaign, and a showcase of clean, tactical rallying under pressure.

events.title: 2001 Acropolis Rally (Greece)
events.bio: Colin McRae battled brutal heat and bone-shaking terrain to win the 2001 Acropolis Rally, claiming his third victory of the season and solidifying his reputation as a master of endurance rallies.
events.details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 2001 Acropolis Rally (Greece)

Date: June 8–10, 2001

Start Location: Athens, Greece

Finish Location: Athens, Greece

Total Distance: ~1,100 km (estimated full route)

Competitive Stages: ~376 km

Surface: Gravel

The 2001 Acropolis Rally proved once again why it's considered one of the toughest events on the WRC calendar. Under searing Greek sun and across jagged mountain terrain, Colin McRae outlasted both rivals and the elements to secure a dramatic win — marking his third triumph of the season and pushing Ford firmly into the title fight.

🗺️ Route Details

The rally wound through the rocky, arid landscapes of central Greece, with relentless elevation changes and punishing stage surfaces. Key stages included:

  • Bauxites: Harsh gravel roads carved into mountainsides — infamous for tire-shredding rocks and blinding dust clouds.
  • Athikia: A fast and flowing stage but scattered with loose boulders and deep ruts from prior passes.
  • Drossochori: Tight and technical with poor traction and punishing compression dips that tested suspension limits.

Temperatures often soared above 40°C (104°F), creating added stress on cooling systems, tires, and driver stamina.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Colin McRae & Nicky Grist (Ford Focus WRC)

2nd Place: Harri Rovanperä & Risto Pietiläinen (Peugeot 206 WRC)

3rd Place: Carlos Sainz & Luis Moya (Ford Focus WRC)

McRae drove with precision and restraint when needed, attacking only where conditions allowed. Rovanperä impressed with raw speed but suffered minor delays, while Sainz played the long game and secured another valuable podium.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Ford Focus WRC: Reliable and tough — handled rocks, heat, and distance with fewer issues than rivals, allowing both McRae and Sainz to finish strong.
  • Peugeot 206 WRC: Light and agile — fast in the right hands, but more vulnerable to rough impacts and mechanical wear.
  • Subaru Impreza S7 WRC: Durable but slightly off the pace on the roughest Greek gravel — struggled to match Ford’s consistency here.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Rock Hazards: Tire and underbody damage were frequent — success depended on avoiding hidden obstacles and choosing protective lines.
  • Driver Heat Stress: Cabins reached extreme temperatures — hydration and endurance management were as crucial as outright speed.
  • Suspension Durability: Repeated hits and landings tested the car setups — the Ford’s reinforced components held up best.

Colin McRae’s victory in Greece was a masterclass in grit and control — a rally won not just with speed, but with intelligence, experience, and unbreakable determination.

events.title: 2001 Rally New Zealand (New Zealand)
events.bio: Richard Burns delivered a commanding victory on New Zealand’s fast, cambered gravel roads, expertly guiding his Subaru Impreza S7 WRC to his first win of the season and reinforcing his status as one of the smoothest drivers in the championship.
events.details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 2001 Rally New Zealand (New Zealand)

Date: July 12–15, 2001

Start Location: Auckland, New Zealand

Finish Location: Auckland, New Zealand

Total Distance: ~1,400 km (estimated full route)

Competitive Stages: ~400 km

Surface: Gravel

Set among New Zealand’s sweeping green landscapes, the 2001 edition of Rally NZ once again delivered one of the most visually stunning and rhythmically flowing events of the season. Richard Burns capitalized on his smooth driving style and precise note execution to outpace the field and claim a brilliant win for Subaru on roads that rewarded composure and car balance over raw aggression.

🗺️ Route Details

The stages, mostly located around the North Island, featured world-renowned camber and high-speed sequences. Key stages included:

  • Te Akau North: Fast, flowing and cambered corners that demanded high confidence and clean inputs.
  • Maramarua Forest: Narrow tree-lined stage with changing light and limited margin for error.
  • Whaanga Coast: Technical coastal gravel — stunning views, but no room for mistakes on the tight cliffside sections.

Dry, cool conditions allowed for excellent stage integrity and minimal dust interference — ideal for pushing the limits on the flowing terrain.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Richard Burns & Robert Reid (Subaru Impreza S7 WRC)

2nd Place: Tommi Mäkinen & Risto Mannisenmäki (Mitsubishi Lancer Evo VI)

3rd Place: Marcus Grönholm & Timo Rautiainen (Peugeot 206 WRC)

Burns led from early on and kept Mäkinen and Grönholm at bay with flawless execution. Mäkinen drove consistently, while Grönholm recovered from an early off to fight back onto the podium.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Subaru Impreza S7 WRC: Exceptionally balanced and stable — the long wheelbase and symmetrical AWD gave Burns the confidence to glide through New Zealand’s flowy stages.
  • Mitsubishi Lancer Evo VI: Strong traction and reliability — consistent but slightly off the ultimate pace over the cambered surfaces.
  • Peugeot 206 WRC: Nimble and quick in transitions — excelled in tight areas but required a clean run to maximize its performance on New Zealand’s wide gravel arcs.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Cambered Corners: Mastering the natural banking was essential — incorrect placement could cost both speed and grip.
  • High Average Speeds: Required early commitment to notes — Burns’s precise coordination with Reid gave him a clear advantage.
  • Limited Margins: With minimal braking zones, any mistake on entry or exit could cost critical tenths — consistency ruled over aggression.

Richard Burns’s win in New Zealand was a shining example of technical mastery — proof that smooth is fast, especially on the world’s most flowing rally stages.

events.title: 2001 Rally Finland (Finland)
events.bio: Marcus Grönholm thrilled his home fans with a flat-out victory at the 2001 Rally Finland, mastering the rally’s legendary jumps and high-speed gravel with supreme confidence in his Peugeot 206 WRC.
events.details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 2001 Rally Finland (Finland)

Date: August 24–26, 2001

Start Location: Jyväskylä, Finland

Finish Location: Jyväskylä, Finland

Total Distance: ~1,200 km (estimated full route)

Competitive Stages: ~385 km

Surface: Gravel

The 2001 Rally Finland was another high-speed spectacle through the pine forests and crests of central Finland. Marcus Grönholm delivered a dominant home performance, flying over the rally’s iconic jumps and flowing corners with unmatched confidence to claim victory in front of thousands of passionate fans.

🗺️ Route Details

Often called the “Grand Prix on Gravel,” Rally Finland is known for its wide roads, high-speed flow, and precision demands. Key stages included:

  • Ouninpohja: Fastest stage of the rally — blind crests, long straights, and multiple airborne sections challenged drivers’ nerve and pace note trust.
  • Lankamaa: Smooth and wide, ideal for carrying momentum and rhythm through long gravel arcs.
  • Ruuhimäki: Famous for the final jump — required commitment to finish with flair and confidence.

Weather was dry and favorable, allowing for some of the fastest stage times seen all season, with most top drivers averaging over 120 km/h.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Marcus Grönholm & Timo Rautiainen (Peugeot 206 WRC)

2nd Place: Richard Burns & Robert Reid (Subaru Impreza S7 WRC)

3rd Place: Tommi Mäkinen & Risto Mannisenmäki (Mitsubishi Lancer Evo VI)

Grönholm took control from the start and maintained a commanding pace, with Burns giving strong chase but falling short. Mäkinen brought home a popular third for Finland in what was likely his last competitive showing on home soil at peak form.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Peugeot 206 WRC: Agile and planted — its short wheelbase and quick direction changes made it ideal for Finland’s flowing rhythm and crest landings.
  • Subaru Impreza S7 WRC: Strong high-speed stability — Burns maximized its grip and weight balance on long sections but couldn’t match Grönholm’s mid-corner rotation.
  • Mitsubishi Lancer Evo VI: Reliable and fast, though nearing the end of its competitive lifecycle — still capable of podiums in the hands of Mäkinen.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Pace Note Precision: Finland’s speed meant co-drivers had no margin for error — rhythm and timing were crucial to maintain momentum over crests.
  • Jump Landings: The car’s ability to absorb impacts and stay balanced dictated confidence levels on airborne sequences.
  • Pressure to Perform: Grönholm carried the weight of expectation but thrived on it — his intimate knowledge of every meter of road gave him the edge.

Marcus Grönholm’s win in Finland cemented his place among the greats at home — a flawless display of control, bravery, and speed in one of rallying’s purest and fastest events.

events.title: 2001 Rallye Sanremo – Rallye d’Italia (Italy)
events.bio: Piero Liatti claimed an emotional home win at the 2001 Sanremo Rally, mastering the technical Ligurian asphalt stages in his Subaru Impreza WRC and delivering a popular victory for Italian fans.
events.details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 2001 Rallye Sanremo – Rallye d’Italia (Italy)

Date: September 20–23, 2001

Start Location: Sanremo, Italy

Finish Location: Sanremo, Italy

Total Distance: ~1,050 km (estimated full route)

Competitive Stages: ~355 km

Surface: Asphalt

The 2001 Sanremo Rally returned to a fully asphalt format through the narrow, winding roads of the Italian Riviera. Piero Liatti, known for his tarmac prowess, delivered a brilliant and composed drive to win his home rally in front of adoring fans. It marked a rare non-works victory in a highly competitive WRC field and one of the highlights of Liatti’s career.

🗺️ Route Details

Sanremo’s asphalt stages wound through the Ligurian hills, featuring steep climbs, tight switchbacks, and little room for error. Key stages included:

  • Colle d’Oggia: A legendary uphill stage packed with hairpins and tarmac transitions — crucial for building early rhythm.
  • Bajardo: Flowing but technical — punished brake fade and overdriving on downhill segments.
  • Perinaldo: Extremely narrow and twisty with blind crests and frequent grip changes — demanded inch-perfect precision.

Weather remained dry and sunny for most of the rally, favoring clean tarmac specialists like Liatti and placing tire compound choices at the forefront of team strategy.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Piero Liatti & Carlo Cassina (Subaru Impreza WRC)

2nd Place: Gilles Panizzi & Hervé Panizzi (Peugeot 206 WRC)

3rd Place: François Delecour & Daniel Grataloup (Ford Focus WRC)

Liatti held his lead through consistent top-three stage finishes, while Panizzi showed his usual blistering speed on tarmac but lost time early. Delecour rounded out the podium with a clean, efficient drive that kept Ford in the manufacturer points battle.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Subaru Impreza WRC: Refined for tarmac — balanced and responsive with excellent braking stability, perfect for the Ligurian mountain roads.
  • Peugeot 206 WRC: Agile and aggressive — quick through transitions but suffered from early setup issues in changing temperatures.
  • Ford Focus WRC: Strong chassis and grip — not the outright fastest, but reliable and consistent through every loop.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Hairpin Mastery: Sanremo demanded perfect brake modulation and early turn-in on narrow, climbing hairpins.
  • Pace Note Timing: Visibility was limited in many corners — co-drivers played a huge role in keeping rhythm intact.
  • Pressure of a Home Win: Liatti handled expectations with grace, delivering one of the most satisfying results of his WRC tenure.

Piero Liatti’s win at Sanremo was a celebration of Italian rallying — a fan-favorite triumph forged through patience, precision, and mastery of tarmac driving.

events.title: 2001 Cyprus Rally (Cyprus)
events.bio: Jesús Puras shocked the WRC field with a dominant win at the grueling 2001 Cyprus Rally, taking his first and only World Championship victory and marking Citroën’s breakthrough moment with the Xsara WRC.
events.details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 2001 Cyprus Rally (Cyprus)

Date: June 1-3, 2001

Start Location: Limassol, Cyprus

Finish Location: Limassol, Cyprus

Total Distance: ~1,000 km (estimated full route)

Competitive Stages: ~322 km

Surface: Gravel

The 2001 Cyprus Rally delivered blistering heat, rocky mountain roads, and one of the season’s most unexpected results. Jesús Puras handled the brutal conditions with surgical control and speed, claiming his maiden WRC win and giving Citroën their first World Rally Championship victory — a significant milestone ahead of their full-time entry in 2003.

🗺️ Route Details

Centered around the Troodos Mountains, the stages were slow, tight, and extremely punishing on both cars and drivers. Key stages included:

  • Foini: Narrow, technical, and rough — demanded tire preservation and sharp reflexes in the dust.
  • Lagoudera: A relentless climb with ruts, rocks, and tight blind bends that punished overdriving.
  • Koilani: A mix of open mountain tracks and tight, shaded sections that fluctuated in grip and visibility.

Despite mild dust, conditions were dry and brutal, with cockpit temperatures often exceeding 50°C — making endurance and car preservation the keys to survival.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Jesús Puras & Marc Martí (Citroën Xsara WRC)

2nd Place: Colin McRae & Nicky Grist (Ford Focus WRC)

3rd Place: Carlos Sainz & Luis Moya (Ford Focus WRC)

Puras led from early on and kept a clean, steady pace through the rock-strewn stages. McRae and Sainz were fast but played conservatively to secure manufacturer points, while others faltered under the intense mechanical strain.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Citroën Xsara WRC: Agile and highly responsive — its debut-spec suspension and tight turning made it perfectly suited for Cyprus’s narrow terrain.
  • Ford Focus WRC: Tough and reliable — McRae and Sainz both leveraged its durability on Cyprus’s harsh roads.
  • Peugeot 206 WRC: Struggled in heat and roughness — suffered multiple suspension issues and pace falloff across the stages.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Technical Endurance: Cyprus’s low average speeds and punishing terrain required maximum concentration and finesse — one mistake could break the car or the rhythm.
  • Dust & Heat: Visibility and temperature were critical factors — cockpit cooling and tire temperature control separated contenders from DNFs.
  • Pacing the Event: Puras showed perfect balance — never overextending and preserving the Xsara for the final day push.

Jesús Puras’s Cyprus triumph was one of the most memorable breakthroughs of the 2001 season — a dramatic debut win for both driver and manufacturer, proving Citroën was ready to fight at the highest level of the sport.

events.title: 2001 Tour de Corse – Rallye de France (France)
events.bio: Jesús Puras dominated the 2001 Tour de Corse with a commanding tarmac performance, guiding the Citroën Xsara WRC to a second consecutive win and proving its strength as a serious asphalt contender in the WRC.
events.details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 2001 Tour de Corse – Rallye de France (France)

Date: October 5–7, 2001

Start Location: Ajaccio, Corsica

Finish Location: Ajaccio, Corsica

Total Distance: ~1,000 km (estimated full route)

Competitive Stages: ~394 km

Surface: Asphalt

Known as the “Rally of 10,000 Corners,” the 2001 Tour de Corse delivered another intense tarmac challenge along Corsica’s narrow and twisting mountain roads. Jesús Puras was untouchable throughout the event, using his asphalt mastery to take a second straight win for Citroën and establish the Xsara WRC as a premier force on sealed surfaces.

🗺️ Route Details

The rally featured long stages filled with blind crests, constant direction changes, and little margin for error. Key stages included:

  • Vero–Sarrola: Tight rhythm sections with minimal runoff and lots of hidden apexes.
  • Pont de Casaglione: Fast descent into winding valley roads — favored drivers who could trail-brake and rotate quickly.
  • Murzo–Ambiegna: Classic Corsican test of concentration with varied surface grip and complex sequences of left–right transitions.

Weather remained stable, allowing full attack on slick asphalt setups across all three days — perfect conditions for specialists like Puras to shine.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Jesús Puras & Marc Martí (Citroën Xsara WRC)

2nd Place: Philippe Bugalski & Jean-Paul Chiaroni (Citroën Xsara WRC)

3rd Place: François Delecour & Daniel Grataloup (Ford Focus WRC)

Puras led from stage one and was never challenged, while Bugalski made it a Citroën 1–2 with his own elegant display of tarmac speed. Delecour delivered a consistent and safe drive to round out the podium on a rally filled with retirements and small errors.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Citroën Xsara WRC: Ultra-nimble and precise — delivered unbeatable rotation and braking under tarmac-specific geometry and damping.
  • Ford Focus WRC: Strong and well-balanced — competitive in mid-speed sectors but struggled with turn-in sharpness compared to the Xsara.
  • Peugeot 206 WRC: Quick but suffered setup imbalance over longer loops — tire degradation limited pace toward the end of stages.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Corner Density: Corsica’s stage layouts demanded exceptional pacenote delivery — one late call could cost an entire loop.
  • Braking Technique: Trail-braking and tight rotation were essential — the Xsara’s platform allowed deep braking with fast directional change.
  • Driver Patience: Success required precise aggression — pushing too early in a stage often led to tire fade or errors later in the loop.

Jesús Puras’s victory in Corsica capped a perfect run on the asphalt, proving his supremacy on twisty roads and solidifying Citroën’s arrival as a serious WRC force — a sign of even greater success to come.

events.title: 2001 Rally Australia (Australia)
events.bio: Marcus Grönholm sealed an emphatic win at the 2001 Rally Australia, mastering the ultra-fast forest roads of Western Australia to boost his title defense in the Peugeot 206 WRC.
events.details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 2001 Rally Australia (Australia)

Date: November 1–4, 2001

Start Location: Perth, Western Australia

Finish Location: Perth, Western Australia

Total Distance: ~1,200 km (estimated full route)

Competitive Stages: ~381 km

Surface: Gravel

Rally Australia’s trademark high-speed gravel routes and narrow tree-lined roads returned in 2001, offering a true driver’s challenge. Marcus Grönholm delivered a clinical and confident performance, combining pace with surgical precision to score his fourth win of the season — keeping Peugeot in the championship hunt and asserting his dominance on fast-flowing gravel.

🗺️ Route Details

Held in the eucalyptus forests around Perth, the rally featured some of the fastest average speeds of the WRC season. Key stages included:

  • Ballingup: Wide and flowing gravel — rewarded confidence and aggressive pacenotes.
  • Wellington Dam: Technical tree-lined roads with shifting light conditions and soft shoulders.
  • Mundaring Super Special: A head-to-head crowd pleaser with parallel tracks and jumps under stadium lights.

Dry spring weather created dusty but grippy conditions, placing emphasis on clean lines, early braking, and effective road sweeping strategy.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Marcus Grönholm & Timo Rautiainen (Peugeot 206 WRC)

2nd Place: Richard Burns & Robert Reid (Subaru Impreza S7 WRC)

3rd Place: Carlos Sainz & Luis Moya (Ford Focus WRC)

Grönholm built a lead early and managed it expertly through the high-speed tests. Burns maintained pressure throughout, while Sainz delivered another reliable podium to aid Ford’s manufacturer standing.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Peugeot 206 WRC: Agile and responsive — perfect for Australia’s fast transitions and precise turn-in requirements.
  • Subaru Impreza S7 WRC: Excellent high-speed grip and stability — Burns pushed it hard but couldn’t close the gap.
  • Ford Focus WRC: Tough and dependable — lacked the final tenth of pace but showed great balance and tire wear management.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • High-Speed Risk: Narrow tracks at 180+ km/h through trees left zero margin — even small mistakes could be catastrophic.
  • Dust Trails: Starting position and road cleaning were crucial — Grönholm capitalized on optimal placement and clean air.
  • Stage Consistency: The rally rewarded rhythm and repetition — making co-driver timing and mental focus essential to maintain pace.

Grönholm’s win in Australia reaffirmed his supremacy on fast gravel and kept his title hopes alive heading into the season finale, capping a near-flawless drive through one of the most flowing rallies of the calendar.

events.title: 2001 Rally of Great Britain (United Kingdom)
events.bio: Marcus Grönholm wrapped up the 2001 WRC season in style with a dominant win in the foggy and rain-soaked Welsh forests, mastering the slick conditions in his Peugeot 206 WRC to secure the manufacturers' title for Peugeot.
events.details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 2001 Rally of Great Britain (United Kingdom)

Date: November 22–25, 2001

Start Location: Cardiff, Wales

Finish Location: Cardiff, Wales

Total Distance: ~1,250 km (estimated full route)

Competitive Stages: ~379 km

Surface: Gravel (wet/muddy)

The 2001 Rally of Great Britain brought the WRC season to a dramatic close in the damp, fog-covered forests of Wales. Marcus Grönholm drove with clinical precision on treacherous surfaces to take victory — his fifth of the year — helping Peugeot clinch the manufacturers' championship in an event defined by thick fog, deep ruts, and mental endurance.

🗺️ Route Details

The event featured legendary forest stages across mid and south Wales, with rain and mud making traction and visibility a constant battle. Notable stages included:

  • Myherin: Fast and flowing with long straights and hidden crests — deep fog made navigation particularly treacherous.
  • Sweet Lamb: A fan-favorite arena stage featuring water splashes and technical rhythm sections.
  • Dyfi: Slippery, cambered corners and tree-lined ditches — one of the most technically demanding of the weekend.

Weather throughout the rally was cold and rainy, resulting in deep mud ruts, standing water, and limited daylight — a quintessential British rally test.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Marcus Grönholm & Timo Rautiainen (Peugeot 206 WRC)

2nd Place: Richard Burns & Robert Reid (Subaru Impreza S7 WRC)

3rd Place: Carlos Sainz & Luis Moya (Ford Focus WRC)

Grönholm delivered a balanced, mistake-free drive while title rival Burns pushed hard but fell short. Sainz’s consistency secured a critical third place for Ford, but it wasn’t enough to deny Peugeot the championship.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Peugeot 206 WRC: Remarkably agile in low-grip conditions — quick rotation and strong traction gave Grönholm an edge on slick surfaces.
  • Subaru Impreza S7 WRC: Extremely stable under braking and acceleration — Burns used its balanced grip to keep pressure on Grönholm throughout.
  • Ford Focus WRC: A proven all-weather machine — consistent but lacked the sharpness to match Peugeot’s pace in these conditions.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Fog and Rain: Visibility dropped to just meters in some stages — pace note clarity and timing were absolutely crucial.
  • Mud Ruts: Deep and unpredictable — wheel placement had to be perfect or risk spinning, aquaplaning, or puncturing.
  • Season Pressure: With titles on the line, maintaining mental composure under slippery and deceptive conditions was key to success.
